GlyphDrawing.club is a modern grid based text art editor. It can be used for making custom modular typography, illustrations, concrete poetry and Unicode art. The editor is inspired by old-school ASCII art editors, but brought to modern times. With the editor you can use any font and any glyph to create your compositions, so the possibilities are endless. The editor also comes with a custom 4x4 typeface for making modular designs.

Whether we are working, dwelling, forming and performing relationships in digital interfaced living spaces its all framed by defaults, which influence how we experience interactions. If we already accepted the default, how can we find a way to seek out some quality in its elements. By translating default interface elements and their behaviour and relating them to my body I am creating a personal and intimate perspective on default interfaced environments I am dealing with every day.

This is Where We Jump is a nonlinear, exploration video game about Jump’s curiosity towards They. As Jump, the player is sent to explore the strange land where They are. As the game progresses Jump collects several fragments of stories, which gives clue about how They think. TIWWJ is a third person video game that uses the principle of scavenging from shooting games not to collect weapons but instated fragments of stories.

titel: If everything is so smooth, why am I so sad? / User — Agent
inhoud: Today, any inhabitant of a city is treated as a computational User by default. Smooth interfaces and real-time feedback loops augment our urban experiences, making us feel empowered, while subjecting us to processes of profiling, quantification, optimization and isolation. Through a series of texts, interviews and algorithmic lyrics, Anastasia Kubrak investigates what it means to be a human User in today’s technological infrastructures. How can Users gain more agency and be re-politicized?

A set up that adds a fun factor to production. Shooting clay balls onto a mould with a high-pressure trigger gun spices up both the process and the end result. When it comes to product design, there is an increasing concern for the user. But what about the producer, the labourer and the craftsman? Romain Kloeckner offers a playful alternative for the usually alienating tasks of the workers at production belts. Choose your clay, load up your gun and experience the thrill of hitting the target on the wall — which happens to be a mould. ‘Made With Pleasure’ adds a fair amount of joy to ‘just another day at the factory’ and proves that play can be productive. It is still pressing a button, but it’s an exhilarating button.

A series of banners made of dirty cleaning rags as a protest in support of women’s rights, showing empowering statements that have escaped from the dirt. Inspired by the Black Protest in Poland, Ola Korbanska embraced the cliché that cleaning is a women’s job to make her point. By taking their undervalued chores out of the house and into the open, she publicly questions the suppressed position of women worldwide. By ostentatiously scrubbing significant public places — a church, a governmental building, a square or a statue — she gave the act of cleaning a special significance. As the cloth soaks up the dirt, the taped off letters acquire meaning and form a clear message: ‘no woman no kraj’, meaning: no woman, no country. Dirt is captured and exposed to convey a message.

Interior objects that play with the tension between durable and disposable. The things you break, rip, tear or crumple usually end up in the bin. We throw away a lot, sometimes for no reason at all. And we all feel slightly guilty about it. At the same time, it feels good to get rid of things. ‘Guilty Pleasure’ explores these mixed feelings by combining what’s worth keeping with items that are easily discarded. A wooden bench with paper upholstery will wear and tear over time. A side table made of melted hoisery grows with each ripped pair. And rocks of concrete get a shiny new surface with the fragments of a broken mirror.“Allow yourself to consume destruction.

Collages made from the abundant images in 3D model libraries, illustrating the overload of visual information that we face every day. Rosanne Ahyi questions the overwhelming accumulation of shapes and textures on those digital platforms, and set out to create an object that testifies to their randomness, complexity, and even absurdity. By combining unrelated images into alienating illustrations, she gave them new value. Some have been brought to life as statues; not simply 3D-printed as the library suggests, but made with more freedom, to revive authenticity. Apart from a few 3D prints, the parts were cast from resin and plaster, cut from Styrofoam, found, or bought at second-hand shops. It’s about the desperate human need to interpret everything we see.

A happy family of functional objects that proudly show their unique anatomy, which has moved away from archetypical conventions through the hands-on approach of their maker. How can designers free themselves from the standard and obvious? Lukas Saint-Joigny started to rethink the functionality of objects, leading to the creation of new forms that trigger the imagination. He started from scratch with undefined material fragments, and without a preconceived form plan. Choices were made as the objects grew, relying on the properties and possible functions of the material. The end results have no obvious reference to existing furniture; they tell the story of their own making instead. I want to show how objects were made, instead of hiding their anatomy.

An analysis of flags as national symbols, freeing them from any right-wing claim and showing how they could be an unbiased symbol for all. This project was triggered by the rise of nationalism and xenophobia in Poland and the use of the flag in this political context. Anna Kic investigated the official rules that apply to the flag and bent these into a more democratic approach. Four Polish flags showcase the official cleaning, folding, hanging and disposing instructions, treating the flag as a simple piece of cloth. Further experiments show how the object acquires symbolic meaning, by cutting out the emblem, blurring the colours, or interweaving the Polish and European flag. Symbols should belong to everybody.

These ornamental architectonic elements originate from images of massively dumped trash, bringing something we prefer to shut out back into our surroundings. We collectively partake in the creation of immense collages of junk. Elissa Assaf was struck by the repetitive nature of the images of the trash crisis in Lebanon, and at the same time fascinated by their form language. To challenge their ephemeral nature, she translated them into ceramic pieces. By digitally morphing the images from 2D to 3D, and milling these into plaster molds, she transforms these digital landscapes into a material archive. The glazed columns become symbols of a serious waste problem by manifesting decay as a disruptive form of art. The fragmented surfaces of trashed objects reveal a language of decline. Realised in collaboration with Sundaymorning@ekwc.

These public seats are reserved for women only, encouraging them to claim their space in a way that comes naturally to the opposite sex: confidently leaning back, legs wide apart, and not worrying about what everybody else might think. Whereas society still expects women to look, stand and sit like elegant ‘sculptures’, Anna Jensen has sculptured a context for a new ideal world; where women feel free to behave as men do. The pink seats — coloured with the make-up women are ‘supposed to’ put on their faces — show provocative body language, with protruding legs, buttocks and even more. Their shape uplifts anyone seated on top, forcing them into a self-assured, ‘manspreading’ pose. I want to challenge the boundaries of conventions.

A collection of domestic objects with an undomesticated look and feel. Instead of trying to control the material, Elissa Lacoste let it run wild in a primitive design process. We live in an era where matter is formed by moulds and coated to the point of perfection, regardless of its natural textures. ‘Grotesque Matter’ plays with a primeval gut feeling, embracing the wild and rough, reminding us of where we once came from. Randomly poured blobs of foam, concrete, copper or silicon grow into pieces of furniture, lamps or carpets. Turned upside down, the flat bottom becomes a tabletop or a seat, exploring the boundary between our drive for control and the forces of nature. There is no need to make things extremely efficient or perfect.

These vases challenge the minimalistic approach of modern Swedish design and claim that everyday crafts deserve a respected place in the heritage of Sweden. Erika Emerén wants to update traditions and defies the sober conventions dictated by her homeland’s cultural institutions. Why not approach high-end design as a delicious treat? In ‘Ornament Now’ the crafty decoration technique of a Swedish Spettekaka cake is the starting point for a new ‘form language’ in ceramics. Traditional Spettekaka is made by piping batter onto a rotating tube. By replacing the dough with clay, a folklore tradition finds its way into design. These layered centrepieces introduce a new mindset to Swedish heritage: more is more. Swedish design narrated as abundant cake decorations.

These ambiguous objects play with perception as they balance on the border between innocence, sex and food. Childish imagery of cartoons and toys have something strangely in common ground with that of erotic imagery, says Hala Tawil. Both represent the world in a perfect and delicious manner. ‘Gradual Unease’ investigates this type of kitschy imagery, and the mechanisms of desire that lie underneath. The forms of these glossy meats and sweets were inspired by the food Hala spotted in children’s cartoons. Made of resin-coated papier- mâché, they create their own fun setting in a slightly unsettling way, which is emphasised by their strangely small scale. Where do we draw the line between what we need and what we want?

How do we perceive nature? This man-made garden rethinks the relationship between humans and plants by questioning the ethics of their cohabitation. We tend to see ourselves as the centre of the universe, detached from our surroundings. Minji Choi counterposes this anthropocentric vision with a more hybrid approach. Instead of manipulating the environment into our own ‘ideal’ world, her garden showcases a more democratic array. With a series of tiny interventions, the ‘natural’ and the ‘artificial’ are interwoven, highlighting the ambiguity of the traditional division. Flourishing or withered, plastic or organic, manicured or bewildered: the plants in this garden attempt to change our conventional attitude towards nature. Plants also have their own dignity.

Instead of hiding its inner self under an industrially polished outer layer, this furniture collection proudly exhibits what it’s made of: wood! The surface of many products does not show the material that lies underneath. Modern techniques can make plastic look like steel, glass or solid wood. This dishonesty creates an emotional distance between us and our objects, says Sho Ota. With this project he wants to revive our appreciation of genuine materiality. Instead of working the wood until it is smooth and uniform, he highlights the natural grains and knots — even exaggerating them with carved out patterns and extensions. Newly grown branches demonstrate what these knots once were. True tactility returns, reminding us of the origins of our furniture. Many surfaces have become a disguise.

A cabinet that explores the evolution of contemporary making, showing that the 3D printer is just another tool for the creation of craft objects. Many people view traditional crafts and additive manufacturing as opposites, but not Aaron Garlick. Defining craft as ‘handmade’ is a mistake, he says. After all, haven’t artisans always used tools to make their products? These 3D-printed miniatures are detailed models of 120 traditional tools that are used to build an old-fashioned wooden cabinet ‘by hand’. The digital technique and the artificial material allow the objects to be scaled down to dollhouse size. Displayed in a polyester resin vitrine with a classic shape, they welcome 3D printing as the next step for contemporary craftsmen. Craft did not stop with pottery and woodcarving.

A bath that represents the internal conflict of the designer: should he always choose for a sustainable design to save the planet, or does he allow himself the empowering freedom to create anything he wants? Fascinated by the forces of nature, Giorgio Gasco wanted to capture the wild and pure feeling of the Romantic painting the ‘Wanderer above the Sea of Fog’. But nature is no longer what it used to be. Should designers accept or fight this? With this organic-looking, yet synthetic bath, Giorgio creates a new context for reflection. Ignore the non-decomposable material and the waste of water for a minute. Just step in, relax, and ponder the incoherence of human nature; it might inspire great new thoughts and solutions. I went into the garden to look for a stone, but I found a plastic bottle.

An animation to initiate a discussion about exclusion and inclusion, using ethnic influences in the architecture of Indonesian border posts as an example The architecture of Indonesia’s seven border posts incorporates elements of the building style of the ethnic majority, reinforcing their already strong presence. Yasmin Aryani analyses this, questioning the choices made in the context of ongoing inter-ethnic conflicts. Indonesia is home to 1,300 different ethnic groups spread over 34 provinces. When one ethnicity is officially linked to a particular territory through references to its traditional housing style in the architecture of border posts, what effect does this have on other non-indigenous and minority populations? Where do they belong? Referencing the architecture of dominant ethnicities to represent the national identity can exclude minorities.

A presentation that reveals how the barriers erected to prevent suicides reflect conflicting requirements dictated by mental health, government policy and public opinion. Barriers and nets are increasingly installed on high bridges in an effort to prevent suicides. As physical manifestations of the line between public life and private crisis, they are tools used to tackle a problem, while the public demands that they be invisible. Kirsten Geekie compiled statistics — dates, materials, heights, fatalities, and so on — about 30 sites and presented it as infographics. Using Google Earth, she created a video that captures the mundane reality of the bridges, an effect enhanced by digital speakers that convey sounds recorded on the bridges. A barrier is a physical representation of private crisis in the public realm.

We increasingly evaluate objects through their representation as images circulating on the Internet, which offers a particular set of criteria and circumstances for viewing and for making value judgements. A method for selecting and presenting objects as images in a museum. The objects are introduced through video and audio fragments, and on the natural habitat of Internet images: screens. Failure to acknowledge the relevance of the image, especially as it circulates on social media, devalues the culture of a generation within the history of visual culture. Context, the setting and circumstances in which an object exists, determine its value.

An exhibition that traces the emergence, myths and promises of the compact disc. Once ubiquitous, and now almost obsolete, the CD is used here as an allegorical device to critique futures with a sell-by date and the hyper-consumption that technology stimulates. Josh Plough selected 11 objects that, when placed together, create an alternative understanding of the CD, creating a space where our technological past and present is open to interrogation. Technology, be it a CD or Amazon’s Echo device, is never a standalone object. There is always a constellation of things surrounding it, from environmental degradation to worker exploitation. Yet, exhibitions and media coverage often fail to connect the dots that compose the entire picture. I created this as a novel approach to the stale technology criticism surrounding us.

Hollow clay bricks that can be filled with raw ingredients and stacked together to make a temporary outdoor oven. The bricks build social ties through a shared cooking and eating experience. Inspired by the age-old process of brick firing in East Africa, this collaborative project aims to put social interaction back on the menu and celebrates community spirit. At a Bricknic event, each participant is provided with a brick to fill with the ingredients of their choice. Everyone then gets together to discuss the plan, build the oven, light up a fire and cook the food inside the bricks. Afterwards, the oven is taken apart and it’s time to eat! Let’s build and eat! This project was realised in collaboration with the German Römertopf company.

A spice collection made up of the molecular compounds responsible for different tastes. The flavours are modelled in cocoa butter to reflect their individual chemical structure and can be grated over food. There are around 11,000 aroma molecules that trigger our taste. These are found in natural foods, but can also be synthesised. The molecular compounds are the same, yet we somehow see artificial aromas as inferior to the ‘real’ thing. But nature cannot produce the sheer volume of compounds needed to flavour all the products on supermarket shelves. By demystifying man-made aromas and adapting them for easy use in the kitchen, we can become acquainted with a more viable culinary approach for a future scenario of limited resources. I want people to discover an infinite palate of possibilities.

An installation that makes us aware of the communication skills of plants by giving off natural fragrances; each scent delivers another message. Merle Bergers has translated the magnified details of a tomato plant into a tactile piece of art, oozing a mist with familiar plant scents. Three selfmade perfumes address the nose just like plants do: ‘attract’ is flowery and sweet, ‘repel’ has an acid note and ‘defend’ smells of freshly mowed grass. The accompanying film, made through a microscope, shows how it works in real life. By realising plants are living, communicating creatures, and recognising their meaningful perfume, we might learn to treat the green scene with more respect. After all, we need it to survive. Plants are living beings with their own language.

titel: Feed The Flesh: Food Guilt In Four Acts
inhoud: A play that addresses the topic of ‘food guilt’. This is the guilt we feel when eating foods that we believe we shouldn’t for ethical, health, environmental, or cosmetic reasons. Two protagonists dramatise two conflicting motivations when it comes to food choices: the ‘societal’ and the ‘carnal’. Smells such as fresh bread and bacon function as sensory props, helping to induce a ‘gut-level’ audience experience. The script incorporates a range of personal, academic and anecdotal research. In a world of abundance, the balance between desire and responsibility in choosing what we eat can become a daily conundrum. This play invites us to take a look inside ourselves and the conflicts that underlie our dietary decisions. We need to take an introspective look at what influences our food choices.

A scenario for a no-flush society, based on objects that redefine our approach to the treatment of human waste in a way that does not use up natural resources. A fictive UN programme that inludes a grinder filled with organic materials, an organic bowl that works on a vacuum principle, a petrol station toilet voucher, a container for transporting human fertiliser, a medicine with a depollutant, and much, much more. Nathan Fordy challenges society’s ‘flush and forget’ approach to toilets, which pollutes drinking water and breaks the cycle of nutrients. Huge quantities of natural resources are used to relocate bodily waste. To counter this, he aims to create a more sustainable alternative. I want to enable a no flush society.

A self-built truck to harvest, process and cook seaweed on site at locations across Europe. Ruth Klückers invites people in to taste her hand-picked produce and shares her knowledge, inspiring conversations on the future of food. Plentiful in the wild, eco-friendly and highly nutritious, seaweed has been used by man since our earliest history. It is time to open our eyes again to the potential of this rich natural resource. Harvesting seaweed is ruled by the moon, the tides and the swell. And so Ruth adapted her lifestyle to the rhythm of the ocean. Inside her truck is a collection of objects, found items or designed tools that all tell the story of seaweed. I’m living my design.

Tears captured in a piece of jewellery as a precious reminder of a moving moment. Crying in public may feel embarrassing, but why be ashamed to show your feelings? These pearl gems showcase the beauty of past emotions and cherish the story behind them forever. Merle Bergers discovered how to extract the minerals from tears and transform these into gemstones. They get their shine from a secret baking process in the high-temperature ceramics oven. As the composition of every tear is different, each gem carries the personal signature of the person who cried it. I see them as souvenirs of bygone emotions.

A collection of interviews, reminiscences and drawings that attempt to understand, implement and reflect upon the practice of communicating with animals intuitively. There are those who believe in the equal importance of all species and the possibility for them to communicate with one another telepathically. By taking this idea seriously, the project questions a humanocentric worldview in an age when this stance seems to threaten the future of ecosystems. Clara Montrieul spent time getting to know a group of telepathic animal communicators. With their help, she quizzed her own two chickens to discover their design preferences and made a research book based on their answers. The first book ever to be co-designed with hens.

Choreographed body movements and gestures that enable people to program and code together with others. Programming is a skill that is increasingly required in the working world, but the only people who seem capable of doing it are those who can sit staring at a screen for hours. It is a physically lonely and static task. Alvin Arthur makes it a collaborative and active task. Using the ‘Processing’ software and Labanotation principles, Alvin devised a way to code through ‘Body. Processing’, a language that merges choreographic gestures and sensor technology. It involves the whole body, not just the fingers on a keyboard. Coding with ‘Body.Processing’ requires physical imagination and expression from the dancer-programmer.

Research on what it takes to grow and season a salad with leftovers from the human body. Thieu Custers used his hair for soil, urine for fertiliser and sweat for salt. With a greenhouse that brings hydroponics to the next level. The closed system uses the residues of his bodily functions — that normally go into the sewer or dustbin — to grow lettuce, radishes, chives and basil. Instead of pouring our waste down the drain, why not use it to sustain life? Hair provides structure for roots, and urine contains indispensable phosphates that the earth is running out of. Harvesting this from our own body presents a sustainable solution: shunned waste is turned into a valuable commodity. Our bodies are part of the cycle of energy, whether we like it or not.

A plan to reforest the whole of the Netherlands by 2060 to create a holistic, eco-friendly, treebased society. The project reveals possible scenarios of a radical green future, integrating trees into our lives. It is our responsibility to explore innovative proposals to change how we use the planet’s resources. Reforestation would improve the quality of life in cities and stimulate sustainable agriculture, while strengthening our ecosystems through natural conservation. Trees are good for climate stabilisation, soil regeneration, recreation and general happiness. They can also provide nutritious food such as nuts, which could be made into hazelnut milk, acorn bread or cheese made of fermented walnuts. These have the potential to become Dutch staple foods of the future. Let’s make the Netherlands the first truly green country on the planet.

For a mere 5 cents this slot machine reveals a secret about the price of a lost life and offers you a small reminder in return. The meat industry’s slaughter practices are kept far away from the consumer. Adelaide Lala Tam wants us to rethink the value of a cow’s life by transforming the brass cartridge casing of the stun gun — the only thing left over from the killing process — into an everyday object. After inserting 5 cents, you see a short movie and the machine produces a paperclip. It is made of the same 0.9 grams of brass for the same price as the cartridge casing, representing both the monetary and the ethical value of a cow’s life. It’s mass-produced, cheap and easy to forget.

Three expressive trophies address the exploitation of the milk cow, which has been transformed from a farm animal into the ultimate milk production machine. Did you know that the production per cow has increased by 61 percent over the last 25 years? And that there is a special award for farmers whose cow has produced 100,000 litres of milk? By adding three more prizes to this human-centred milk madness, Adelaide Lala Tam questions the morality of it all. There is an award for the cow that is ‘always fertile’ and another one for the cow whose calves are ‘always female’. The third one, with the supersized udder, is waiting for the animal whose milk production is ‘always increasing’. The milk cow faces devaluation while the dairy industry keeps booming.

An installation that creates a physical taste sensation without showing edible ingredients or releasing their scent. Just looking at five expressive faces on screen already activates the taste neurons in your brain. ‘Digital Seasoning’ reminds us that elements like colour, texture and facial mimicry can create or intensify the perception of taste. The project forges a link between two human addictions — screens and food — and opens up new possibilities for the food industry: to create more intense flavours with less unhealthy ingredients. There’s a face for each taste: sweet, sour, bitter, salty and umami. Meet them all and find out who’s the one with a sweet tooth and who leaves a sour tang. Our mind creates taste expectations before food reaches the mouth.

A research project that combines coastal engineering with saline agriculture, re-introducing a forgotten vegetable with the reinforcement of the Dutch Afsluitdijk dam. Where most plants die in cold salty sea winds, sea kale flourishes; this protected species grows naturally along the coastline. Mathilde Nakken developed an innovative breeding programme that celebrates this taste of Dutch heritage. Moreover, it calls attention to the global need for saline farming. A new concrete structure strengthens the dike and at the same time provides ample growing ground for this primeval plant. Underneath the lids, tasty sprouts grow in the dark. Visitors can cut these, or the kale’s flower buds, at harvest feasts and tours — or try them at local restaurants. Sea kale links coastal engineering to Dutch cuisine.

A study of the visual language used by charities to convey the value of mercy. Ishtar (Wei-Chen) Hsu takes the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation as a case study. This Taiwanese NGO has over 10 million members in 47 countries. The foundation has a highly successful global communication strategy. By analysing its methods, it is possible to understand how the foundation is able to engage so many people. Ishtar (Wei-Chen) Hsu uses the sociological concept of ‘collective action frames’ to study the foundation’s television documentaries. She colour codes the characters, classifies the metaphors used, as well as gestures such as giving, and signs of cooperation. The colours help to expose what is happening in each image. By cataloguing communication methods, you understand what works.

A digital journal that serves as a stress management tool for adolescents. It combines the benefits of a private diary with interactive features that offer comfort when needed. Oldashioned paper journals are losing ground to social media platforms like Instagram. But with this shift, important qualities are lost: instead of secretly writing down your deepest thoughts, the whole world is watching, and the pressure to be ‘perfect’ is high. ‘Dear#Me’ offers more online privacy and the freedom to be yourself. Users can choose between a private or public mode, and share information completely anonymously. Moreover, they don’t have to fit into a standard format, but can design their own interface instead. Social media platforms are not a safe place for teenagers.

A narrative installation raising awareness and inviting discussion about the gruelling office hours that are the norm in Japan and the phenomenon of ‘karoshi’: death from overwork. “When you’re at the office 20 hours a day, you don’t even know what you’re living for anymore,” tweeted Matsuri Takahashi, a young woman who worked at a top Japanese advertising agency. She killed herself a week later. It’s one of too many similar stories. Sayo Kato came up with a plan to address this issue. What if employees could empower themselves by conveying Matsuri’s Twitter posts for all to see, via the façade of her huge former office building simply by moving the window blinds to form the letters and words? The installation shows just how difficult it is to change things.

By targeting Twitter hashtags that embody extreme opinions on topics such as global warming, the refugee crisis and LGBT rights, this project seeks to demand a more nuanced view than the black-and- white world of the original tweet. Whenever the algorithm comes across hashtags such as #sendthemhome, the bot asks questions such as: ‘Who are they?’ ‘How do you send them home?’ ‘Where is their home?’ Users are then sent to the online project platform that aims to answer these questions by providing information based on reliable sources. With a relentless tide of populist propaganda in public digital discourse, it’s time to cultivate an understanding of the complexities of modern issues. We need to keep asking questions instead of accepting easy answers.

This project explores the potential of humanbot collaborations. Through projections and podcasts a speculative scenario unfolds, in which designer Karin Fischnaller teams up with her synthetic alter ego: the design bot Karin Anders. Together they investigate how technology will influence the design profession. Karin is in need of somebody who supports and reflects on her work: is her artificial companion up to the job? Karin’s newborn digital colleague is not a design tool, but an equal partner that can complement her and vice versa. She has built an installation that introduces her personal bot and offers a platform for discussion: step into the circle to hear what various experts have to say on the matter. Artificial Intelligence will prompt fundamental changes in the design world.

An app, online social platform and movement to bring food production back into cities, encouraging people to grow their own and exchange resources and knowledge. Today’s food economies are not sustainable environmentally, and the long, complex supply chains are causing an increasingly deep chasm between people and their food source. From rooftop gardens to community food banks, the project examines how Singapore’s existing food and related resources can evolve with technological platforms that assist sharing and collaborative economies, potentially shaping food production and consumption for future smart cities. Technology can help us to localise our food sources.

The culture and history of a dish that takes the shape of a cookbook. The history of Semur, a type of stew cooked by braising ingredients for a long time, reflects the evolving relationship between Indonesia and its former Dutch colonists. The dish is a vehicle for understanding the complex colonial mechanisms of two merging food cultures. Although it draws from the cookbook format, this book represents more than just instructions for preparing food. Exploring cultures and history, and the transformation of a dish in terms of identity and exchange, the book sheds light on the colonial and postcolonial relationship between Indonesia and the Netherlands. Food generates a larger narrative beyond its palatable experiences and flavours.

‘Encyclopaedia on the Human Obsession with Absolute Knowledge’. That’s the subtitle of these reference books. Their content shows that — even with contemporary knowledge tools like Google — it’s hard to find and present information in a universal way. Google seems to have all the answers, but did you know that search results differ per person? The information on your screen is personalised according to your location, language and time. Each of the five volumes offers the same 100 Google references on paper. Yet they are completely different, due to changed settings during the search. It becomes clear that our most popular search engine presents a pre-edited world. Which leaves us with a new question: does universal knowledge even exist? The books reveal the problematics of the politics of search.

Younger generations and people from other cultures often don’t understand traditional Korean ‘Gugak’ music. By making the music more visual, Suk Go aims to increase its appeal. By creating a music score that visually reflects the nature of the different sounds, from plain notes, to trembling tones, listeners gain an extra insight into what they are hearing. As an extra visual aid, a 3D model of the handkerchief used by traditional dancers flutters in response to the music. Sinawi is an oral music genre within Gugak; the notes are never written down. Being able to see the notes and rhythms in a custom music score helps make the music more accessible. By visualising traditional Korean music I hope that more people can enjoy it.

An alternative strategy for branding the city of Málaga that doubles as a platform for connecting activists, residents and tourists. Málaga, like many cities, has branded itself to attract international tourists, corporations and investors. But at a price. Vacant buildings and an exodus of local residents are the reality behind the guidebook image that emphasiszes the birthplace of Pablo Picasso. A city map showing buildings with preserved facades but nothing behind them serves as a metaphor for cultural impoverishment. Collectives present alternative strategies in a video, and an online platform (www.consumingthecity.com) translates their knowledge so that citizens can connect with it, empowering them to share their own information. My role is to mediate between collectives, inhabitants and visitors to Málaga.

A collective imaginary of what Europe is, translated into an online platform and series of video narratives that explore European identity. European citizens can live, work and study anywhere within the European Union. But who are the ninety million young people living in foreign countries across Europe today? How does the transience of these people shape their identity? In the context of rising nationalism and anti-EU rhetoric, how dto they build a community? Mar Ginot Blanco distributed forty 40 disposable cameras to young citizens currently living in a foreign country, and asked them to visually answer the question: ‘How does Europe influence your everyday life?’ A reading of the images reveals a European policy residing in each of them. European identity is borderless and shaped by the mobility of its citizens.

A record of arson attacks against refugee and immigrant accommodations since the reunification of Germany in 1990. Germans pride themselves on having confronted the horrors of the Third Reich, but fail to face the rise of right-wing extremist culture in recent decades, Thomas Stratmann finds. By confronting people with the ugly effects of growing nationalism and xenophobia, he aims to show that the need to protect against violence is as urgent today as ever. Burnt scale models represent the buildings attacked to translate abstract numbers into a visual reality. They give a physical presence to a heritage of hatred that is spreading in society and the parliamentary system. Recognising the historical parallels.

A modular system to connect individual balconies to one another. This communal space stimulates interaction, with planters further helping to spark contact. Social isolation in cities is on the rise: up to two-thirds of urban inhabitants suffer from this. Poorly designed communal spaces are part of the problem, as are elevators that take people directly up to their door. While travelling, Edwin van Capelleveen was inspired by apartments with communal gardens for people to relax, share a meal, or grow plants together. He realised that balconies, often used only for storage or hanging laundry, could be extended to create a practical, social solution. These balconies transform dull, outdated facades into lively, inviting buildings.

This ‘memorial’ stick contains data that you have selected to share with your loved ones when you die. The average internet user has around 90 online accounts. What to do with these after death? Some information you want to keep alive, other things you would rather see deleted. ‘Data Mortis’ is an internet service that takes care of such personal online data in an appropriate manner. Apart from the function that ends all accounts with one click, the system offers a cloud for documents that you want to safeguard. After your passing, these files are transferred to the memory stick. Those who find it in the mail can plug in to remember you. It is hard to delete a loved one’s online presence.

This concept shoe is made from a single thread of polyurethane. Inspired by the open and strong webs that spiders build, Martin Sallières experimented with 3D-weaving techniques, creating a similar structure for footwear design. By tweaking the properties of the material, variations in density, flexibility and thickness become possible. The mesh is created with a constant back and forth movement along the shoe last; by heating the result, the shoe keeps its form after removing the mould. This shoe is like a concept car, made to push limits, change trends and explore the future. The initial experiments are just as important as the final outcome, showcasing a new approach to footwear design. Why make a shoe out of different pieces and materials?

Designed as a peaceful intervention in the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine, ‘Grey Borders’ aims to raise awareness of the daily struggles of people on both sides. A documentary reveals the personal stories of those living near the border, and a VR experience allows people to encounter the places that most don’t, won’t or can’t go because of the conflict. As a believer in a world without borders, Lithai Cohen Pletain researched how people’s freedom of movement is limited along the Israeli-Palestinian divide. The project is a way to demonstrate the irrational nature of physical boundaries. It’s about letting the stories be heard.

A stool made using high-tech printing techniques and based on the specific measurements of each individual user. Not only do the dimensions change, but the design also differs every time. We are surrounded by data. Yet, this often remains abstract and intangible. Addressing this, Henri Canivez aims to translate data into a physical object as a design methodology. The weight and height of the lower body is measured. Then, a custom algorithm generates a micro-architecture based on this data. The algorithm automatically generates denser structures when needed, for extra strength. The final design is 3D printed in two versions: one uses PLA bioplastic and the other is made from aluminium, nylon and glass. This is about bringing the user back to the origin of the creative process. The project was realised in collaboration with CNC Speedform.

Footwear designed to be everlasting, made up of different elements that can be easily replaced when worn through. Just snap, clip, or tie on a new part instead of buying a new pair. This project is a response to the throwaway culture of fast fashion, where mass-produced low-quality sneakers quickly end up in the rubbish heap after minimal use. Every shoe can be customised to the wearer’s individual taste or mood. From the straps, to the uppers, all of the assorted parts come in different materials and colours for infinite combinations. For an everlasting sneaker.

An additional set of lungs for top athletes of the future. This sports wearable optimises oxygen levels by keeping the airflow constant, improving performance by a few percent. With this project, Martin Sallières presents a lighter take on transhumanism. Machines don’t have to be a threat. Why not embrace their potential instead, with a non-invasive wearable? It is still a concept, but it can be done: breathe the way birds do, with air sacs that allow a continuous and more efficient flow through the lungs. As the ultimate front-runners, eager to push themselves to the limit, athletes will be the perfect ones to test this new respiratory system for mankind. The human body has reached its limits; transhumanism is part of our evolution.

‘TENSION’, a collection comprising a mirror, a desk lamp and a pencil case. We use elastic bands for all sorts of things, but Matthieu Muller was amazed to discover just how useful they are for connecting and holding parts together. As the name implies, his ‘Tension’ collection uses the tension in silicone elastic to connect the parts of the stainless steel mirror, the Plexiglas and brass desk lamp and the anodized aluminium pencil case. The band acts as the centrepiece of each product, defining its look and strengthening the identity of the whole collection. Remove the elastic and the parts can be stored or shipped as a flatpack. Simplicity can be a complicated thing.

An adaptable ventilation system for flexible office spaces. We spend 90 per cent of our time indoors, much of it at work, where we cannot control the temperature. Either too cold or too warm, our focus is disturbed and our productivity affected. ‘Séole’ consists of two elements. One radiates heat through far infrared technology, the other produces a light breeze by its irregular rotation. You can adjust the position of both elements, regulate the temperature and alter the intensity of the breeze. By focusing on the action of cooling and heating, Séole proves more effective and pleasant than general air conditioning systems. Moreover, it can be adapted to individual and collective needs. Feel the warmth of the sun and cool breeze of the wind.

A set for making your own perfume at home. Use it to distil fragrant oils from natural ingredients like orange peel, flowers or pine needles. Then, it’s a matter of mixing your favourites to suit your mood and personal preferences. Smell acts on the brain’s limbic system, the area associated with memory and feeling. It can have a powerful effect our emotions. But why be dependent on anonymous laboratories and inflated prices if you can whip up a scent yourself? A bottle of the famous Chanel No. 5 perfume sells for almost €90 in the store, but the scent itself only costs €2.13 to make. It’s like cooking: with a good cookbook everyone can make something tasty.

A radical rethinking of an iconic design to bring the design process to another level. Humans have created a parallel dimension, the virtual world. It is a realm where everything is possible. According to Baptiste Labat this world of limitless possibilities should help us understand how we can stretch the boundaries within our own dimension: the physical world. Using the technology of 3D-animations, Baptiste has pushed the envelope on a design archetype, the Thonet chair. It offered him a new attitude towards design creation. By animating the chair he gave movement to a static object, giving it a new look and feel. But the most dramatic effect: instead of an object, the design becomes an experience. “Use the virtual realm to free your mind!”

A ceramic research project that explores textures, open structures and patterns made possible by a custom-made dripping machine. Interested in combining digital technologies and craft with a human touch, Carla Joachim and Jordan Morineau created a new machine that drips liquid porcelain, allowing them to create a new ceramic language. The machine drips liquid clay through a nozzle with a diameter that can be changed. The drops fall onto a rotating plaster mould that also moves on an X axis. Carla and Jordan wrote a code that determines the speed and movement of the platform, and hence the ceramic outcome. They can exploit the possibilities to produce a unique result every time. Our machine links crafts and industries. Project done together with Jordan Morineau. First photograph by Ronald Smits. Second photograph by Pierre Castignola.

A multi-purpose cabinet that is easy to customise. The colours and textures are inspired by different travel destinations, so you can go new places with your interior. Whether it is the vibrant pulse of a megacity, the peace and serenity of a snowy landscape or the light sea breeze of the ocean that your mood longs to take you, with ‘Wanderlust’ you can journey a different world, right in your own space. With the neon-andblue hues of a Tokyo night, soft, wintery tones of a Finnish forest, or the sea-green and ochre sand of Sardinia, Leandra Eibl recreates local colour palettes with tinted acrylic and perforated aluminium panels. Exploring the moods and atmospheres of different places.

A porcelain colour grid and series of tableware exploring how tinted clay and semi-transparent glazes work together to create different hues. Choosing the colour tends to be one of the last steps in design. The shape and function have been defined, and the colour is added as a layer on top. Why not consider the colour in an earlier phase? The semi-transparent glaze allows the original clay to show through towards the rim, whereas the shape of the products encourages the glaze to pool towards the bottom, becoming more intense in colour along the way. The resulting gradient shows all the shades in between. With three colours of clay and 25 glazes, Simone Doesburg explores 75 variations. The possibilities are endless. I’ve let the colours define the character of the design.

A pinball machine that visualises the flow of personal data, making kids aware of their online tracks in a playful way. Children grow up in a digital world without understanding the true value of personal information. Through their smart phones and tablets they leave traces all over the internet without realising it. This fun game shows the score and boosts awareness. Sixty balls represent the data, which cover all aspects of daily digital life — from chat history to photos and online purchases. They bounce past interested parties: data traders, the government, supervising authorities and criminals. Hitting the data-trader pop-bumpers wins you points, but beware of getting hacked: then it’s game over. Do we continue to play this game, knowing that we forfeit our data?

This online service suggests training plans that best fit your personality, making it easier to incorporate regular exercise into your life. Ever felt like sports are just not for you? In same way that we look for a partner to fall in love with, we should seek our ideal match in sports. A competitive extrovert will be drawn to different activities than an outdoorsy introvert. This is for all who have yet to find a sport they enjoy. Users fill in a detailed questionnaire to help the service identify specific personality types. A tailored exercise plan or dietary advice is then drawn up based on this information. Exercise should fit in with our lifestyle instead of vice versa.

A furniture range that exploits the intrinsic quality of bamboo. Bamboo grows easily in the fertile soil near Zhiya Huang’s home town of Chengdu in central China. However, ancient craft techniques are threatened by the emergence of new products such as compressed bamboo board. Zhiya wants to breathe new life into the culture of bamboo furniture. Zhiya worked with a craftsman to explore new joints and new uses for bamboo. Her stool and bench feature an innovative connection in the frame that showcases the material’s natural properties. She also limited the number of steps needed to make the pieces. No glue or nails were used in the process. Compressed bamboo is not bamboo.

These raincoats are designed to play outside in the rain by making inventive use of the rainwater. We call rainy days bad weather, but when they become the standard we may have to change that view. If the earth warms by 2 degrees Celsius, the Netherlands will face many more days with heavy, persistent rainfall. So why not change the perspective of the next generation, by celebrating rainy days? These raincoats come alive when the skies cloud over. One has a fun funnel in the sleeve, while another collects water in tubes sewn into the hem, and a third unfolds to form a big receptacle for a carry-on puddle. Is it raining? Let’s go out and play!

Lamps powered by gravity. Fascinated by the purpose of analogue systems in a digital world, Jordan Morineau wanted to create objects that highlight the beauty of mechanisms based on gears and weights. Each of his lamps showcases the mechanism that makes it work. Jordan created two types of lamps: one works with ballast, the other with its own weight. In both cases, gravity is exploited to put pressure on a gear, making it rotate and powering the LEDs. Rotating the structure restores the parts to their original position so that they can descend again and power the LEDs. What object do you use if electricity disappears?

A ceramic research project that explores textures, open structures and patterns made possible by a custom-made dripping machine. Interested in combining digital technologies and craft with a human touch, Carla Joachim and Jordan Morineau created a new machine that drips liquid porcelain, allowing them to create a new ceramic language. The machine drips liquid clay through a nozzle with a diameter that can be changed. The drops fall onto a rotating plaster mould that also moves on an X axis. Carla and Jordan wrote a code that determines the speed and movement of the platform, and hence the ceramic outcome. They can exploit the possibilities to produce a unique result every time. Our machine links crafts and industries. Project done together with Carla Joachim. Additional photography by Pierre Castignola.

Chairs inspired by the principle of ‘Minimal Surface Tension’ - letting the laws of nature govern the design. By experimenting with small-scale models of metal frames in different shapes and dipping them in soapy water, Nando Dolleman discovered that physics fills in the rest, instantly creating surfaces spanning the gaps. Translating this principle to furniture design, he stretched textiles over large frames to create chairs. The same method can be applied to create endless variations. You can get a computer to calculate all the angles and structures, or spend hours sketching the ideal lines, but why not leave some design decisions to natural forces? I design the frame, but nature designs the shape.

A series of fine-dining tableware that heightens the multisensory experience of eating by exploring the synergy of food and design. There is much more interplay between our senses than previously thought. The shapes, colours and textures of the dishes used to serve our food all influence our eating experience. This is the realm of gastrophysics: a new, interdisciplinary field applying principles from neuroscience, physics and chemistry to gastronomy and cooking. Teresa Berger worked closely with Floris van Straalen, head chef at Michelin-star restaurant Envy in Amsterdam, to develop tableware for an eight-course menu. In each piece, she focuses on one or two sensory cues other than taste, linked to the origin or the preparation of the food. In addition to taste, we react to what we see, hear, smell and touch.

Ceramic serving dishes that can be used on both sides for extra flexibility in presenting different foods. Sharing food together is a moment of celebration. This series honours the beauty of this moment, combining appeal with extra functionality. Being able to use both sides of the dishes saves cupboard space, as every piece has multiple possibilities. Anna Ballmann turns tableware design on its head: by using the form of both the top and bottom of a dish, she creates two presentation surfaces where there is usually only one. The dishes are like a changing landscape.

An experience that celebrates the fine qualities of chocolate and presents it as the luxury item it once was. Chocolate has become a product of worldwide mass consumption, but not of mass production. Cocoa bean farmers are getting less money for a difficult crop that increasingly suffers from climate change. A worldwide shortage is at hand: time to revalue this extraordinary product. Stephanie Bakker has teamed up with a confectioner for a setup that tickles the senses. ‘Xocolatl’ offers a taste of chocolate heaven: tactile 3D-printed structures, super shiny chocolate bombs, crunchy chock rocks or a finger-licking cocoa sauce. The utensils to prepare and serve them add to the thrill and make you crave for one thing only. Chocolate is like good wine; an exhilarating luxury.

A clothing rack with a portable steamer to freshen clothes, so they don’t have to be washed as often, which is better for the environment. Frequent washing is bad for your clothes, uses lots of water and releases countless tiny synthetic fibres into rivers and oceans. Airing or steaming clothing lets you wear it again without laundering. Extending the life of clothing by nine months would reduce carbon, waste and water footprints by around 30 per cent each. A garment should last a lifetime; that’s only possible with the right care.

This collection of lamps combines two additive manufacturing techniques. Man-made, 3D-printed frames continue to grow after the printing is done, developing their own crystal skin. The process of 3D printing and the formation of mineral crystals seem worlds apart, but are actually based on the same principle, slowly materialising layer by layer. Fascinated by their similarities and differences, Felix Mollinga managed to manipulate them into a co-creative unity. Both materials need a day to complete their part of the structure. The printing is controlled, precise, and industrial. The crystals are unpredictable, stubborn, and organic. One strengthens fragility and the other adds sparkle and translucency. The frames are identical, their skin is unique.

A comfortable two-seater sofa that fits a small living room, but also has the secret option to multiply itself. Slide out the armrests and two chairs appear that can be used both inside and outside. Are you longing for a picturesque porch? A lovely living room? And an end to your struggle for space? This ingeniously handcrafted furniture set meets all your wishes. The seats are completely waterproof and dirt repellent, which makes them perfect for the garden. When the outdoor season is over, they are easily integrated into the sofa again. By sitting down, their position is locked; you can set them free by getting up! I want to bring the outdoors in.

A range of women’s underwear to improve health awareness. Women’s lingerie is made of a range of materials, many of them synthetic. Women wear it without stopping to think how these fabrics, which are in direct contact all day with their most intimate parts, affect their bodies. With her range made of natural fibres, Levien Lodders intends to raise women’s awareness and change their choices. An abstract video inspires women how they should take care of their bodies to stay healthy. The natural lingerie helps put this idea into practice. The material is breathable and absorbent and it keeps bacteria in check. The pattern reflects the effect of the fabric on the body. What you wear against your skin should help you stay healthy.

A new campaign method to help NGOs spread awareness using objects designed to be photographed, liked and shared on Instagram. With more than 800 million active users per month, Instagram can become a vector for change if used as a tool for activism. A street demonstration tends to reach far fewer people than a photo posted by an influencer with millions of followers. With bright colours and photogenic, eye-catching designs, Mariska Lamiaud created three products that work well on Instagram: a giant blue whale seat for outdoor events, a selfie mirror and Antarctic wildlife bath bombs. Designed as playful props, they also highlight issues like plastic in the ocean and threats to marine ecosystems. Influencers get a great photo, while sharing awareness of issues that matter. The textiles for the blue whale seat were supplied by Vyva Fabrics.

Furniture for storing stable equipment made from dried horse manure as a sustainable base material. The series is an example of what is possible, aimed at inspiring the industry at large. Manure has been used for housing for centuries, especially in Africa and parts of Asia. Why not use it for furniture? After researching traditional manure construction techniques, Martijn Straatman set about creating a manure-based material with similar properties to chipboard or MDF, but more eco-friendly. It is made up of 80 per cent manure, chalk, water and biodegradable glue that is mixed, pressed into a mould and allowed to dry. To become more sustainable we have to go back to the basics.

Smart compression stockings that emancipate wearers. The cost of compression stockings is high, because they wear fast and because putting them on and taking them off requires help. And needing a nurse twice a day limits people’s independence. NI-TI is doubly emancipating: wearers no longer need assistance, and they can choose a pattern or colour they like. Out with generic brown, in with self-expression! The material used is a shape-retaining, durable nickel titanium, Nitinol. At room temperature, the stocking’s knit is wide, making it easy to slip on. Body temperature makes it shrink to fit the leg. Apply a coolpack to loosen it again and take it off. I want to offer people a sense of self-worth and a personal touch. NI-TI socks were made by Knitwear Lab and sponsored by Knitting Holland

Wooden furniture that showcases the natural quality of oak responsible for causing a dramatic change in colour. Oak contains a high percentage of tannic acid. This protects the tree against bacteria and insects. When tannic acid comes into contact with rust, an oxidation process takes place that turns the wood from brown to dark blue. To control and accelerate this effect, Rebekka Evers soaked steel wool in vinegar and brushed the solution onto selected parts before assembling the final product. The colour inherent in the wood itself is allowed to shape the heart of the design, rather than coming as an external afterthought applied at the end. The hidden colour is exposed to the outside world.

Stoma bags redesigned to look and feel better, boosting confidence and helping wearers to enjoy a full and active life. There are three styles with special features tailored to different moments: regular, sporty and intimate. The designs now in use do not fit our modern lifestyle and really limit wearers’ freedom. They are uncomfortable, don’t stay in place, leak and irritate the skin. Teddy interviewed stoma users to assess their needs and wishes, incorporating these in her designs. There is a deflation valve and the flexible material moves noiselessly along with the body. Appealing to look at, they are no longer something to hide away in shame. Current designs are anything but sexy.

A soundscape that makes acoustics visible and tactile. By placing tubes of various materials and dimensions on matching speakers, each sounds gets its own character. Unravelling sound to one instrument per speaker and modifying that sound by hand, gives rise to a playful sound system and spectacle in one. The performer is a composer, musician and designer at the same time. Six 3D-printed speakers serve as the basis for a diverse set of tubes. Connect a tube and a specific sound starts to play. Wood creates a deeper tone, brass makes it purer, and foam has a muffling effect. Variations in length and width allow the composer to finetune his or her masterpiece. This is only the beginning: it’s a growing library of materials and sounds.

Jasper de Graaf has designed a range of household items that can be taken apart into their constituent materials for re-use. In traditional design processes, the concept and aesthetics of a product are in place before the manufacturing details are considered. Decisions are made to get the product to consumers as fast as possible, without much thought for the product’s afterlife. Jasper has overhauled his design approach. Considering manufacturing decisions right from the start has determined the concept development and the aesthetics of his flat-iron, hairdryer and mixer. Their look communicates how the different materials have been put together. Most importantly, it shows they can be easily separated and used again. “I started designing with a product’s afterlife as my first priority”

A virtual reality experience that visualises the vast flow of data that surrounds us. By putting on the VR-glasses you enter a parallel world, where tracked data from local wi-fi points become the building blocks for a dynamic urban landscape. Vito Boeckx found a way to translate actual network activity into a digital city. Screen recordings from nearby modems are turned into huge neon-lit skyscrapers, emphasising the scale of it all; each tower grows when online activity intensifies. We all contribute to this omnipresent yet invisible data flow, which increasingly dominates our lives. Is ‘Dataism’ becoming a new religion? Data Church offers a sanctuary for reflection on our digital behaviour. I want to make sense of something we cannot see or grasp.

‘Digits Untangled’ is a futuristic scenario that explores bodily functions and feelings in an increasingly digital world, treating our skin as a digital interface. What will it mean to have a body when everything is dematerialised? And how will sexual intimacy be perceived? Soline Bredin set up a pioneering peep show that completely rethinks sexuality, presenting it as the brain game Untangle. Two spectators take their position as voyeurs on opposite sides of the peep box for visual, tactile and auditory interaction. They experience the otherness of their own body as knots are tangled and untangled to trigger their desire. They can feel the vibrations of the movement through their haptic jacket and glove. Explicit sex is replaced by symbolic interaction.

This project explores a way to bridge between the differing Eastern and Western approaches to life. Evi-Lie van Heck designed three objects that represent a place of worship in the West. The materials, form and function are inspired by Indian Yogic culture. An explanatory film reveals how to use the objects while also providing context about the design and spiritual meaning. Evi-Lie was struck by how restless we are in the West, and by the fact that we are not always aware of our spirituality. In addition, the relationship we have with objects is usually based on consumption. This project aims to show how we can use materiality for a spiritual purpose. We need to re-establish the relationship we have with objects within a consumer society.

Three standard office seats have been digitally stretched, blown up and morphed. The off-size frames were 3D-printed, then traditionally upholstered and reintroduced into the office. Just as it is important to recycle materials, Moreno Schweikle and Janne Schimmel believe that it is vital to recycle shapes. They took three functionally perfect, yet uninspiring office chair designs, digitally manipulated their DNA, and relaunched them into the physical world. With the help of digital toolkits, faintly familiar mutants are created. An ordinary desk chair is stretched into a three-seater sofa, a lean conference chair is blown up into an overstuffed version and twelve office stools have melted into a majestic lounge chair. We try to bridge the gap between the digital and physical world.

A display of ‘bliss’, represented by the iconic image of the Windows XP desktop background, of lush hills, blue skies and white clouds, as unpredictable textures digitally printed on fabrics. Mainstream representations of landscapes usually depict a perfectly controlled nature, without room for unpredictability. Millie Herpin therefore encourages disobedience to break free from this restrictive culture. By questioning our relationship with common objects, Millie challenges the established criteria of what good design means: Introducing excitement for those who find perfection mundane, and seek authenticity. ‘Bliss.bis’ immerses the viewer in this dreamlike space.The response to the mainstream is the world of dreams.

Clothing based on written descriptions of garments in literature as a new way of initiating the design process. In fashion, words describe clothing after it has been designed. What happens if you start with words instead, so the description determines the design? In ‘The Trial’, by Franz Kafka, clothing is simply a tool to set a scene, or describe a specific act. Take the phrase: “Angrily, he threw the coat onto the table.” Here the anger of the wearer suddenly creates a connection between the coat and the table. Inspired by such examples, Aleksandra Gudkova designed a jacket, blouse and coat reflecting the relationship of each within the literary setting to create a new reality that fits both the object and the individual. I use Kafka’s words to re-read clothing and explore an alternative.

Still lifes, but not as we know them: instead of careful arrangements, these pieces show everyday scenes that we usually ignore. Would you label them as ‘art’ or ‘design’? By shifting focus from the curated and sublime to the ordinary and disregarded, Janne Schimmel questions the status of products: what happens when the context becomes the product? The scenes come from casual snapshots of the designer’s life: a heap of branches in the park, a dead bird on the street, his tabletop after a day’s work. His 3D-scanner and printer allow him to reproduce them as hollow structures with a plastic ‘veneer of reality’. The lamp inside highlights the result: a tribute to the mundane. We unconsciously create still lifes all day.

This interactive installation scans, deconstructs and reconstructs your moving body, creating its own digital interpretation of you — no keyboards, mouse or clicks involved! Technology is more advanced than we think, says Jim Brady. He proves it by using the software from an old Kinect for Xbox to create an extra smart screen. It doesn’t need any of the classic interfaces, not even your touch, to create a personal piece of art. The interaction between man and machine is fascinating. The more people participate, the more interesting it gets. A growing database of human body parts and postures provides the ingredients for a dynamic sculpture. It’s a reflection on the digitisation of the human body.

Not just another water dispenser: ‘Oasis’ revives the value of water with the look, feel and functionality of a romantic fountain. Water coolers are the perfect example of how products can lose their appeal when form becomes inferior to function and producibility. Moreno Schweikle feels that we have been ignoring the beauty of water for too long. This modified cooler is made with the same technique and materials as the ones we know. But the design tells a different story: it refers to the neo-classical drinking fountains at historic city squares. The allegorical figures that are pouring, carrying and worshipping water stress the cultural and social importance of this valuable resource. It is time to reassess the most popular meeting spot in the office.

‘Eclissi Solare’ is an autonomous light installation simulating a solar ecliptic effect. It is based on the concept of Nature’s Mimesis, in which technology is used to imitate the natural world and its phenomena. In an era of advancing technological nature, ‘Eclissi Solare’ plays with our sense of reality. A solar eclipse is a rare event and can produce profound psychological effects. This piece has the power to recreate the intense experience. The installation comes to life harnessing controlled and natural light sources reminiscent of a supernatural event that makes you wonder: what are you actually witnessing? To believe that technology is not part of the natural world, is plain ignorance.

A vlogumentary that explores the discrepancy between the on- and offline identity of a vlogger. Gwendolyn Qwerinto integrated the phenomenon of vlogging into a documentary format to create a new genre: a vlogumentary. The film shows a conversation with her sister and vlogger Roxy. It offers an insight into the presentation of the self, both in front of the camera and backstage, to reveal the mentality of the online generation. Vloggers share their lives on YouTube. By consciously selecting and editing the film footage, they unconsciously censor themselves, posting an ideal self-image as a representation of daily life. But is a vlog a fair representation? And are we still able to discern the staged image from reality? I’m visible therefore I am.

This holographic interface warns you against an unhealthy obsession with social platforms and the absent state that comes with them. When your online behaviour shows signs of addiction, the Spirit Guide — a digital version of yourself — shows up. Scientific research has linked excessive internet use to depression, impulsive disorders and loneliness. As we compulsory scroll, check and click, our mind seems to disconnect from our body. The ‘Obsessiogram’ has been designed to bring us back. It locks accounts when things get out of hand and forces users to reconnect with their body through gestures. To be able to continue, the spirit’s moves must be repeated. The pace depends on the severity of the addiction. We leave our bodies behind when we go online.

A book of poetry that was completely written by a robot that educated itself as an author by processing 800 works of romantic literature — from Tolstoy to Brontë, Joyce and Kafka. Robots may seem autonomous, but their behaviour is shaped by us. Without human authors, this book would not exist. This project explores the relationship between a machine’s performance and our own input. The sentences in the book are made by an algorithm that finds possible patterns in word order, forming interesting new — and grammatically sound — content. What about: ‘I am not going to cry for humans?’ Each word is tagged with an endnote that traces it back to the work it came from, creating the longest reference list ever. The robot has rewritten renowned works of literature.

A visual manifesto on the future of identity as augmented reality becomes embedded within everyday life, extending our perception and expression into the digital realm. Augmented reality (AR) has already started to influence how we present our identity. As technology progresses, virtuality can create intangible layers around our body, determining the image we show in public, enabling digital fantasies to become a reality, and making the physically possible a secondary issue. Clara Escalera explores how AR will shape identity expression by presenting it as a new step in fashion design, which includes colour-changing fur, anti-gravity shapes, and moving patterns. In her vision, clothes will be rendered rather than sewn. Instead of wearing fabric and seams, we’ll be wearing code.

An animated projection on a pregnant woman’s belly that visualises what is actually happening inside. A projector above the examination table shows life underneath the skin: not only the baby’s true size and position, but also how it is fed for example, or how the mother’s organs shift to make space. Although there is a lot of information available about a baby’s development in the womb, it’s all in books or on screen. Many women find it hard to link this to their own body. By combining the standard ultrasounds with these realistic projections, the medical facts become less abstract and more personal. It helps pregnant women to stay close to their bodies.

A taste of life on Mars. This set of products resembling something out of space aviation simulate the physical aspects of a possible extraterrestrial future. Humankind may speculate freely on moving to Mars, but the specifics of actually living there are rarely highlighted. This installation is designed to make it feel more real. Slip on the boots and experience the difference with earth’s gravity. Or try the gloves to feel the numbing effect of space travelling on your hands. The oxygen backpack offers a taste of the ‘filtered’ air that you will breathe, and a climate simulation box hits you with the freezing truth: it’s pretty cold on the planet next to us. I’d like to unveil what it’s really like up there.

‘Fuck being alone’ is a streetwear collection with a focus on crossovers and co-creation, taking the rebellious paintings of daily life by Jan Steen as its inspiration for a new direction. Martijn ‘Tino’ Cimmermans wants to pull streetwear out of its niche and into an inspiring collaboration. In an attempt to leave rivalry behind, he has created the brand ‘Teams Up’, with a mission to stimulate designers from various fields to work together. He invited various artists and designers to develop prints for the new collection, inspired by Jan Steen’s work. Having these screen-printed onto the shirts and sweaters at the launch and pop-up shop put his battle cry — team up! — into effect. We are building an industry of synarchy.

This Virtual Reality experience shows the same protest event from various perspectives, giving you a vivid insight into the world of opinion-making. In this age of information we are quick to form an opinion based on what is published. But there is more than one version to the stories we hear, see or read. Why not try a different view — it might change your judgement. Climb the stage, put on the VR-glasses and enter the scene of a protest march. Be a journalist, a policeman or a protester and see what happens through their eyes. In the meantime the crowd can change the issue at stake by tweeting a hashtag to @mobilejournalism, making the experience even more interactive. Breaking news is never neutral.

‘Unreal Plots’ offers a new form of entertainment that uses the principles of conspiracy to turn everyday trivialities into thrilling tales. We all invent stories — temporary realities that we create in our mind when facing uncertainty. This project shows how easily real events can be manipulated and turned into instant fiction via an app. The story starts when you scan a photo from her own custom newspaper with your phone: it might be Harvey Weinstein’s bathroom, the Kalimantan Olympic stadium or the United States Congress — emptied of people or personal things. An actor shows up on your screen and the plot thickens. Based on recent headlines, a personal narrative begins to unravel: fake news is written on the spot. The news is the effect and you are the cause.

An online platform that introduces a new way of discussing international politics. By telling entertaining stories about everyday situations and comparing those to what is happening with the EU, the subject becomes more accessible to a larger audience. Political jargon scares many people off. At kitchensinkpolitics.nl a new vocabulary is introduced to involve those who feel politics is not for them. Relatable metaphors bring Europe to life: what if Estonia were a young woman living across the hall from a grumpy old man named Russia? Or if your country is a student at the supermarket checkout, coming a Euro short? Once the story grabs you, the accompanying links take you further into the subject. Many people don’t know what the EU does, even though it seriously affects their lives.

An interactive installation that plays with poetry and learns to speak with ‘human’ emotion. The project explores how artificial intelligence deals with linguistic expression. Robots are considered to be cold and impersonal. But that’s how we have made them. Seo-kyung Kim shows that we can teach computers something else, by feeding them with romantic literature and personal notes. This machine operates at the junction between technology and poetry. It asks people to submit expressions of joy, anger, sadness or surprise. With its filled database, it educates itself and starts to create its own metaphors and express its feelings in return. Language is a central facet of human culture.

‘Collective Collection’ is an exhibition concept that visualises social media trends within art exhibitions. To open up a discussion about how social media influences the way we look at art. Collective Collection also describes the tension between a curator’s vision and a visitor’s experience. Using photogrammetry software and pictures from Instagram, Mikaela built up a spatial re-construction of the exhibition. Patterns became visible; areas of the exhibition that were documented less frequently became distorted or were even omitted completely, while well-documented areas — such as around the Mona Lisa — were depicted almost perfectly. Is there a ‘right’ and ‘wrong’ way to experience art?

A bike made of recycled plastic waste in Mexico City. This sprawling metropolis of 21 million people is the largest in the Western Hemisphere, so there is plenty of plastic to harvest. Spending hours stuck in traffic in this city is normal and many urban areas are hard to reach with public transport. Bikes are faster and cleaner, and what better than to use waste material that is cheap and readily available? The bikes are designed for easy production and feature removable parts for handy replacement after regular wear and tear. By making the design freely available on Wikipedia, anyone can build this bike, or suggest improvements. Affordable, quality transportation should be a basic human right.

Make a wish, and this interactive installation will upload it to the collective ‘wish cloud’. This project — a digital exploration of the Japanese Ema ritual — is aimed at bridging the gap between ancient traditions and new media. Whereas Shinto worshippers hang their wishes on public shrines for others to read, this application has a much wider reach: it allows wishes to transcend borders.
