We all wish, albeit in different ways. Masaya has designed a common ground for this universal longing, without having to visit a shrine to leave a prayer or go to a fountain to toss in a coin. Simply swipe your deepest aspirations from your phone into the cloud and watch it come to life through the installation. At its core, it is an abstract human database.

A chair that makes us aware how far below sea-level we live in the Netherlands. Intended to go in the home, it acts as an invitation to discuss within a private context how global issues are affecting us. With rising sea levels due to global warming, Boris Maas illustrates the need to stay safe in lower- lying regions. The unusually tall chairlegs lift you above the tide. Made from smoked European oak, this play on an iconic design piece has no obvious use. It stretches the mind of the observer who imagines living on extensions. How to make a piece of furniture that matters.

A light sculpture that captures the poetry of the night lights. The 24 / 7 mentality is keeping us active at all hours. Boris Maas is calming us down. This light installation is a poetic interpretation of the lights we use in the city at night and the shadows they cast. “An Ellipsis Machine, A City Light” mimics the motion of car and street lights that pass us by as we move through the city at night. From a car light bulb in the centre, a series of overlapping filters and moving armature project ellipses of coloured light. They circle the room, softening our state of mind with their mesmerising effect. As a kid I loved looking through my eyelashes, creating my own blurred landscape.

This coat stand, coffee table and shelf respond to our interaction with them. Proposing a more attentive and intimate relationship with the objects we live with, they push us to examine how we connect with our surroundings. We live in an increasingly responsive world, where our technological devices provide constant immediate feedback. Yet our physical living environment remains static: objects exist in a fixed state, whether we interact with them or not. By including springs into several everyday domestic objects, Jade Chan has made a range of furniture that introduces movement, receptivity and playfulness into our lives. “How can I design everyday objects that are more fun to engage with?”

An on-site installation consisting of a computer, a screen and a webcam that takes portrait photographs of everyone in a particular place and generates a composite image of the average face of all those people. The installation encourages us to reflect on our assumptions about other people. Joep Truijen holds up a mirror to expose our deeply held prejudices. Confronting us with the average face provokes a conversation between us and the screen about the similarities and differences between people everywhere. Each portrait photograph is layered onto the previous photographs, morphing them together to form the average face. This average is then projected onto the portrait of the current user. Holding up a mirror to see those around us in relation to ourselves.

Visitors are invited to wear one of Marica De Michele’s body-modified wearables: a hand-eye glove, a foot-eye sock or a neck-eye scarf. They allow users to explore a new perception of their own body, and self, in relation to their surroundings. With sensory augmentation, the viewer remains just an observer. But ‘Flesh Artifacts’ offers a complementary, active experience: wearing them gives you the physical sensation of having sight elsewhere than in the eyes. These prosthetics allow for new visual perspectives. These are displayed in real time on screens in a three-channel film installation. The content is generated from the movements of the person wearing Marica’s artificial body parts. How does it feel to see the world with your hand, foot or neck?

A kinetic installation in which the simple act of breathing causes a soft textile texture to ripple and flow like the foamy surface of the sea. It is a playful invitation to wonder — together. Only through taking part in the installation does the work transforms and is able to transfer meaning. The more people breathe out, the more dynamic the textile moves. Like a human-generated wind, a wave of energy, a collective breath. Metaphors help us to see with new eyes. They impact our reality and stretch our understanding. Did you know in many ancient languages the ‘mind’, ‘wind’ and ‘breath’ are identical associations? ‘A Collective Breath’ materialises all three in a design metaphor, reacquainting us with a spiritual understanding, in which the concept of mind goes far beyond just brain activity. Amplifying the breath acts as a reminder of our very existence.

‘Wavy Tales’, a documentary that explores how, in a world explained by science and technology, our surroundings are still imbued with storytelling and wonder. People have always told myths and stories back through time, even before we could write. Although today’s world is increasingly understood through science, the impulse to tell stories is as strong as ever. As technology increases in complexity, the mystery grows, and provokes us to create myths again in contemporary life. In her film, Sunjoo Lee asks people how their microwave ovens work. The rumours, fantasies and odd explanations about the invisible and unknown are told with humour and curiosity. The microwave oven is a magical box, inviting to be filled with imagination.

An analogue typographic display consisting of 210 paper ‘sails’ that are rotated by small motors to reveal a black or white side. Together they form a word or expression. Pairs of synonyms appear in succession, highlighting slight nuances in meaning. ‘Angst’ for example, implies a general and existential emotional turmoil, while ‘fear’ describes an emotion caused by a perceived threat. Constantly in motion, this public installation has a mesmerising quality. The paper has a physicality and sound that is more engaging than a screen. It introduces a new and unfamiliar format for presenting typography. The display emphasises the importance of subtle nuances inherent in language.

An interactive installation using a café as a metaphor to explore the idea of guaranteed monthly earnings through a universal basic income. People help themselves to a free ‘cup of basic income’ in the form of coffee from the machine. They can contribute to the communal coffee pot by ‘going to work’ and grinding more coffee. The coffee visualises the flow of money. In one scenario, people get a full cup; in the other, they get half a cup. These are based on recent Swiss and Finnish proposals. The idea is to make this abstract principle more concrete and initiate a discussion about how a universal basic income could work and what kind of basic income people would like. Visitors can experience different economic models at first hand.

An alternative vision of how people could directly influence their digital environment through intuitive physical actions. Clear your cache and cookies by wiping the screen with a cloth, or switch to an anonymous TOR browser by closing your curtains: it’s all possible in this interactive installation. While greatly affecting our behaviour online and offline, the interfaces that mediate our digital surroundings are not transparent enough, believes Martina Huynh. We have too little control over them. We are treated as users of services rather than as citizens with a democratic say in the systems we are increasingly reliant upon. It is time to take direct action. The digital space needs to become more accessible.

To what extent do we allow artificial intelligence to become part of our love life? This short movie presents the pros and cons of an intimate relationship between man and machine. Add an advanced algorithm to a dating app and you get Intispace: a new platform that provides you with digital friends, whom you can talk to 24 / 7, watch movies with and fall in love with — and they will never leave you. But are they for real? Tijnke van Gelder wrote a scenario for a futuristic love story that could come true with state-of-the-art technology. The main character falls for a girl and starts dating her digitally, which makes him quite happy. But when he wants to meet her in real life, things get complicated. Humanising machines is not necessarily a bad thing.

‘Neosolide’ is a women’s collection of garments that are shaped by solid, sculptural accessories, embracing the paradox between rebellious girl power and elegant feminine fragility. Lorette Colé takes a new stance on the use of stiff materials in clothing. Instead of hiding the pieces that support, protect or enhance the body, she uses them as eye-catching fashion statements. These ‘jewels for garments’ celebrate women’s many different desires in how they want to dress. Transparent acrylic sticks act like a magnifying glass on the skin and fabric. Chrome-plated metal pieces play with tactility and light reflection. Sometimes accessorising, connecting, compressing, closing, the items are as versatile as women are — constantly in harmony or discord. Made for an audience that dares and cares about their style, everyday.

Handwoven fabrics that suggest what could be woven in the future by the fashion industry to eliminate waste. It is impossible to ignore the problem of waste within the fashion industry. Sarah Brunnhuber set out to create a minimal-waste garment production technique. She tackled the issue at production level by changing the way fabrics are developed. By weaving pattern shapes directly, Sarah eliminated cutting waste, and by knotting each piece together she eliminated sewing waste. The knots represent the handcraft that is missing in industrially made garments today, while also drawing attention to the need for a mentality change. Celebrating the way clothes are made and visualising the production method.

A collection of modular garment components that reference uniforms. While society encourages individuality, the reality is that many of us live, eat and dress the same way. Sarah Brunnhuber explores the theme of uniformity and eccentricity by introducing a uniform into everyday life: garments without rules. The collection comprises four consistent shapes in fabrics that reference uniforms: plain crisp cottons in blues and whites, rigid navy blues, a static beige. Opposing fabrics highlight the contrast between uniformity and individuality: dark and lightened denims, liquid silks, bold embroidery. A system of buttons and holes connects all pieces, which can be worn anywhere, with any other piece. A clothing system that encourages eccentricity within uniformity.

‘Personal Ornament’ walks the line between jewellery and garment. These hybrid accessories are designed to add a daring twist to any outfit and make you feel brand new. Tired of wearing the same as everyone else? Ready for something new, without wanting to buy yet another dress or shirt? Sabine Tulp designed five eye-catching pieces that extend the life cycle of your wardrobe by adding a touch of glamour to the clothes you have. They are bright and sparkling, and you can wear them anyway you want — just dare to be bold! By hanging and wrapping them around your arms, legs, back or neck, they create an extravagant look from head to toe. I want to celebrate the individual.

A clothing collection that celebrates collectivity instead of glorifying individuality. ‘Teamwork’ embraces football scarves as a common symbol of shared interest and pride. In our increasingly individualistic society we are always being encouraged to distinguish ourselves from others — a mindset the fashion industry gladly supports. Abel Kouwenhoven, who feels that we have become too self-centered in many ways, has designed a clothing line that reinstates the positive power of collectivity. The knit scarves have traditional club patterns and colours, and are emblazoned with phrases from famous football songs, praising unity and companionship. They are sown onto sweaters and jackets and only reveal their message when the proud wearer opens his arms to the people around him. The fashion industry should focus more on communality.

An editorial campaign celebrating ‘multi-locality’, inspired by the saying ‘we are all immigrants’. We should rethink the concept of national identity, says Sia Degel. Instead of asking ‘where are you from’, she asks ‘where are you a local?’. For this project she has translated the cherished characteristics of the places people named and showed her into wearable props, expressing a new, many-sided identity. The local view of a mountain from Reykjavik and the colours of a river in Kolding are combined into a sculptural body suit; a photograph of a loaded cart in the streets of Santiago grows into a picturesque mask. Featured in a fashion shoot, they show the ‘Multi-Locals’ in all their beauty. An immigration campaign visualising the collaged identities of modern nations.

Tufted wearables inspired by animal pelts to impress others and distinguish yourself from the crowd, while also creating a shelter for the human body. Pelts are synonymous with protection, warmth and a dramatic appearance. Chrissie Coerman explored how to recreate a similar effect in a human version through tufting — a technique usually only used for interior fabrics like carpets or rugs. Through extensive material research, Chrissie was able to create voluminous forms and static silhouettes with the tufted loops. Revealing different yarns, patterns, colours, heights and densities, the pieces create abstract landscapes reminiscent of organic shapes. The eccentric pelts instantly transform the body into an imposing animal being. Show the animal in you.

A flowerlike, tongue-in-cheek art and fashion magazine, promising to raise a smile. We live in stressful times. It can overwhelm us and make us far too serious. Lexi Oprean has spotted a pressing need for joy. Noticing the relieving effect flowers can have with their brilliant colours, delicate petals and sweet scent, she took this as her inspiration for a new magazine. Its colourful pages express an off-beat cheerfulness in a range of categories and flicking through them frees the mind. ‘Freevolity’ is liberating in its layout, typography and content. Created entirely in Lexi’s apartment, it shows how small injections of frivolity can change your mood and attitude, making your world a lighter place. Go pick a flower yourself today!

These magnifying and distorting glass panels create the optical illusion of an underwater world. Prints start flowing when you walk by, ink turns into coral, glass becomes the ocean. Kim Melody Zoutewelle screen printed colourful graphic patterns on both sides of glass plates. The glass poles, which are melted onto the surface, act like ripples on water: they add motion, create depth and play with perception. At every angle, a unique and different image is born. A new way to brighten public spaces using glass as a poetic, narrative material. I am fascinated by the refraction of light through water. Made in cooperation with Glasatelier Lichtinzicht

A collection of jewellery designed to serve a shared wardrobe, allowing different wearers to adapt the size or style to their own wishes. ‘Take, make and dispose’ is out of fashion; we will increasingly share, borrow and reuse products — and that counts for clothing too. But shared fashion requires a new mindset. Instead of designing and buying new outfits, we need to find ways to personalise existing designs. With ‘Trashures’ a shoulder width can be altered or a skirt can be shortened without cutting or sewing. By combining materials like precious coral and silver with inferior plastic and glass, the charms emphasise the overall vision of the collection: ‘One man’s trash, another man’s treasure’. Restyling can seriously extend the life of designs.

‘Safety is a Luxury’ is a collection of protective knits — not for policemen, FBI agents or the military, but for ordinary citizens. Worldwide, there are many places where dodging bullets and bombs has become part of everyday life. What if the same would happen to us? Tachisse de Beun’s new clothing line is about feeling and being safe. Bold and imposing silhouettes give the wearer a sense of empowerment and live up to that promise: they are all bulletproof. With a variety of double knitting techniques, ballistic panels are integrated into different structures and layers. Besides being highly protective, these unisex merino wool garments are also comfortable to wear and add a dynamic style to any wardrobe. Safety should never be taken for granted. Made in collaboration with KnitwearLAB and ProteQ Bodygear

This frisbee is part of a manifesto: ‘Design for Freedom in the Age of Information’ (DeFAI). It is a form of activism as education, and education as activism. When thrown, a variety of seeds shoot from three holes along the edges of the disc. Ofer Kantor’s guerrilla gardening tool is the first translation of his manifesto against syndication. A playful yet critical tool for environmental action, ‘Seeder’ protests the formation of an agricultural oligopoly. This iteration of the manifesto teaches people about a global loss of diversification, while diversifying locally. Hands-on hacktivism like this occupies a grey area in the law, making it an opensource and reusable weapon in a fight for peaceful anarchy. People’s freedoms are being undermined, it’s time for uncomfortable, disobedient, rebellious design.

An architectural installation that re-sensitises us to the movement of the wind. In today’s increasingly urbanised environment, we are growing out of touch with nature. Daan Brouwer believes we should develop new relationships with the natural elements through architecture. Because while the primary purpose of a building may be to keep the weather out, most do such an effective job that they inadvertently deprive us of contact with two key requirements for our well-being: nature and change. Daan has built an installation to re-establish the interweaving of nature in human life. The revolving propellers tell us what the strength of the wind is, keeping us in touch with the outside when we are indoors. It’s an architectural ode to our neglected senses.

‘The Condition of Air’ is an ongoing research project into possible new functions for bicycle inner tubes. Inspired by the Dutch bicycle culture, Michela Segato started to rethink a basic part of this popular vehicle: its inner tubes. Her fascination with the successful yet tense relationship between rubber and air led to a playful exploration of new shapes and uses. By binding, restraining or cutting, she reinvented the tubes. They are shaped into knee pads and safety helmets, modelled into fashionable hats, used as a mould and transformed into an array of other inspirational items. The book that presents them invites us to consider the humble inner tube in a whole new way. Adding pressure reveals rubber’s surprisingly athletic properties.

Decorated porcelain vessels as a visual representation of the pollution caused by mass global transport. In the 17th century, colonial traders began shipping their wares across the oceans. The long, perilous transport increased the value of the products: buyers paid more because these special items travelled far. It was a delicate balance. Today that balance has tipped: goods from anywhere in the world are available at low prices. Is this a good thing, or does it demonstrate how careless consumerism has made us? Echoing the past, this installation reminds us of the real cost of shipping to the environment. These delicate vases depict the world’s biggest cargo ships and have been decorated with the carbon they emit. The link between mass consumption and pollution is here in black and white.

An urban green space in which every element communicates information about intangible, macroscopic fluctuations in the financial world. Oscar Rainbird- Chill found links between the economic and natural worlds, in terms of cyclic change, differences in scale, and growth and decay. Because of increasing mistrust towards the financial world, due to our not understanding or choosing not to engage with it, he harnessed nature to help clarify — in sensory ways — the system. Oscar divided the garden into trees, flowerbeds and furniture that symbolise the changing fortunes of institutions. People find themselves surrounded physically by that which defines their lives invisibly, causing them to reflect on their relation to macroscopic events from an unexpected angle. Could a fountain’s intensity of flow match the rate of trade in electricity?

A glass room divider with double-sided mirrors inspired by digital interfaces. A reflection of our need to see ourselves, the mirrors also confront us with our digital behaviour. Social media has turned us into regular showoffs as we pout and pose to broadcast our success online. This self-important behaviour is nothing new, as 18th-century period interiors reveal: stuffed with ornaments to display the owner’s status. In a modern parallel, Elvira von Wieding Lidin brings our digital vanity into the physical living space. Normally we cannot see ourselves as we engage online. In this mirrored screen, we can catch a glimpse that may put our actions in a different light. This is the story of an ornamental species in a digital age. Supported by the Danish Art Foundation

A future technology-rich democracy where artificial intelligence supplies us with information that is in our best interests, unlike today’s world where a handful of tech giants provide us with information that primarily serves their interests: profit. In a world increasingly monopolised by tech companies, we are slowly relinquishing our ability to determine our preferred future. If technology is the new power, ShengKai Hsu asked, could we share this power equally in the future? ShengKai created the ‘Deepself’ installation as a speculative scenario that encourages us to reflect on the present situation. Mirrors invite us to discover our core values and understand how they are shaped by technology. We’re so used to looking at the unknown through Google Search.

A new approach to knits, especially for those who like loose ends. Whereas unravelling is something most of us want to avoid, Maya Leroy has developed it into a new technique that opens up fresh possibilities for the fashion industry. By pulling the thread, a new colour, shape, length or width will unfold. The former disappointment of fabric falling apart will turn into a pleasant surprise, allowing the owner to add a personal touch. The excitement lies within the unravelling, which reveals secret layers in various steps. Imagine a new look for every season: a whole collection in just one piece! The unravelling allows the knit to reach its full potential.

CUT THE CRAP For too long pigeons have been seen as filthy rats with wings. This campaign, inspired by populist parties and political movements, aims to give this unloved bird the podium it deserves. Or is the pigeon a way to tell a bigger story? Populists are masters of communication and manipulation. So what better way to engage the masses than to learn from the experts and make use of their methods? Full of strong, simplistic language and bright visuals, the campaign mimics the way issues are blown up to absurdity, leading to polarised debates where the underlying causes are put aside and left undiscussed. The real issue is polarisation. The pigeon is just a decoy.

An optimistic movement inspired by ‘the fool’ of times gone by. It’s all about taking life a little less seriously, one step at a time. Historically, the fool or jester had a specific role, balancing between amusement and criticism. He was an outsider, cherished for challenging social conventions at the centre of power: the king’s court. Where has the fool gone now? Pauline Wiersema wants to bring him back. With a series of possible interventions, including a Ministry of Fools and giant orange letters spelling out ‘HUH’: a visual sign to shake things up with the universal word signifying confusion. You can also start with yourself and learn how to play the fool again. Let’s all fool around some more!

A look at intellectual property using one of the most democratic designs of our time to reclaim creation: the ubiquitous white plastic chair. The world is full of copyrights, but the system no longer works. Instead of protecting creators and inventors, they are now limiting the creative process. We should be able to improve on existing designs, Pierre Castignola believes. Nobody knows who originally designed the white plastic chair. Yet, numerous remakes are patented. Pierre takes sections of different designs and re-assembles them, to show the ambiguous relationship between patent law and the freedom to create. Imitation is part of human nature.

An exploration into the nature of belongings through a series of lamps. These are designed to redefine our relationship with the things that surround us. Due to mass manufacturing, we hardly get a chance to bond with our possessions. They have become too disposable and interchangeable: there to serve us. It’s hardly the basis for a good relationship. These lamps create more of a connection with the user. One only switches on when you pour it a glass of water. Another needs a scarf to light up, while the third must be tilted, forcing the user to adapt to its individual character. I set out to create an emotion rather than a function.

A design manufacturing system to make objects by the minute. The cost is measured in custom ‘Diego Coins’: every coin is worth a minute of production time and is the equivalent of one euro. Diego Faivre makes products from waste materials such as cardboard tubes, plastic boxes and leather strips in the amount of time purchased. To add appeal, he covers each with colourful ‘Diego Dough’: an air-drying clay. Time really is money. Here, the quality and design of the outcome depends directly on the time spent. This challenges the traditional way we value an object. It is a reaction to the rise of mass production and a lack of individual expression in what is made. I explore the joy of making, of having fun and not being perfect. This project was realised in collaboration with Scrap XL in Rotterdam.

A multitude of surprising and symbolic significations of the egg. Inspired by the perfect shape of the egg, Caroline Cotto gave free rein to her imagination. She sees in the egg an invitation to contemplate ephemeral beauty. After studying the shapes and colours through light and shade, Caroline put the egg centre stage. She made a book filled with observations of the egg as a shape, an object, and sometimes a character. She also conducted colour research in which she presented eggshells as skin colours. Eggs have inspired a multitude of ideas, myths, beliefs, art, religions, recipes and concepts.

Easily accessible instruments that allow everyone to experience the amazing energy of jamming together, regardless of their musical ability. As a musician, Cas van Son knows the power and pleasure of making music with others during a jam session. Inspired by this, he aims to help others interact in this same way. As social beings, it is in these connections that we thrive. The instruments are programmed to communicate with each other and are based on the basic elements of music: rhythm, bass and melody. They are designed to look inviting, so the user can just dive in and improvise. Playing, searching, smiling: diving into the musical adventure together!

A coffee set that questions the idea of ‘normality’ by introducing unexpected variations such as extra handles or missing pieces. In the small town where Doris Verlaat grew up, she never felt quite like she fit in with the accepted local ‘norm’. Daily get-togethers over coffee were a fixture of village life; a time to gossip and discuss who did or didn’t fit the mould. And so with this coffee set, Doris plays with the mould, creating more freedom for differences. At first, the cups and saucers appear ‘odd’ or mismatched, but a closer look reveals that the different elements are the same; they are just composed differently. Nobody is the same, so why should everything be uniform?

A mobile cart inviting people to celebrate individual accomplishments in a personal print made on-site. For events, festivals, street corners or dinner parties. By asking visitors what they are proud of, Kiki van Caspel helps them to translate their stories and feelings into a monoprint. The print is sent to the participant’s home afterwards, as a lasting visual reminder. We tend to focus on all the things that go wrong, without thinking about our many achievements. This project aims to help people adopt a more positive perspective. We hardly allow ourselves to talk about what we are proud of.

An app to help define personal values, remind you of your priorities and ensure that your life choices are in line with what you find important. When the choices you make and the things you do correspond with the values you stand for, life is usually good: you are happy and content. That is why it is so important to make a conscious effort to discover your values. The app takes users through a series of questions and exercises to gradually pinpoint the areas where they will feel happiest setting and achieving their goals. Living according to your values makes you happier. The project was realised in collaboration with Van Lanschot.

An educational tool that visualises the complicated theory of macro-economics in a tangible model for high school students. Did you completely understand what was going on in the Greek debt crisis and where it went wrong? Words are often not enough to explain the practical meaning of facts and figures. That’s why Rik Maarsen materialised them in an open source design. A map of Europe with 3D-printed models of banks and parliament buildings forms the playground for an interactive session of economics. By loaning money for national investments and by reconstructing the events that led to Greece’s troubles, students experience the cause and effect of economic crisis first hand. When words acquire shape, they become easier to understand and remember.

A cycling safari that leads to the Big Five – not in Africa but in the Dutch province of Drenthe. Sheep, goats, cows, pigs and chickens may seem like ordinary farm animals, but this excursion will show you five rare species. Did you know that the Groninger Blaarkop cow is just as rare as the Chinese panda? Or that the Drents Heideschaap breed of sheep almost went extinct a few years ago? This awareness campaign supports the struggling farmers and their special livestock. Want to see the Bonte Bentheimer? Or a Drents Hoen? Get the guide, jump on your bike and follow the map. Don’t forget to take a look at the energising promo first. You do not have to travel to Africa to see interesting animals.

Sara Kaiser explores our increasing life expectancy. A video imagines a future when people live longer through medically enhanced diets, and an interactive installation invites people to take part in a partly scripted discussion. With scientific advancements, our life spans have increased continuously. Some enthusiasts believe that soon we will be able to completely eliminate ageing processes. Predictions like these raise many questions on the moral and ethical consequences of living longer. Sara Kaiser offers a context to explore these. The film translates scientific technologies into a fictional narrative. It acts as a teaser for the role play that allows participants to explore different ideas and opinions on life extension. Future wealth may not only manifest in money, but also in time. Sponsored by Kvadrat

A new production principle that reflects the origin of the used materials, making the global supply chain more transparent and responsible. The raw materials for today’s products come from all across the globe, yet their origin often remains unknown. We miss out on the true story behind a product. Thomas Woltmann has designed a formula that visualises the journey of its components. His formula relates the quantity of the sourced material to the distance it has travelled. The closer the origin, the more you see of it; materials that come from far constitute a smaller part. Applied to a series of wooden ladders, the method calls to mind trees from all over the world. There’s an alienating gap between raw materials and the end product. 114

The world’s first 3D printer that uses paper pulp. There is a growing market for 3D printing on demand. Printing your own or existing designs is now widely accessible. Apart from some expensive exceptions, the print material is almost always plastic. Beer Holthuis was surprised to discover that there are no real sustainable materials or printers on the market. Using the mountain of paper we waste: 80 kg per person per year! The pulp in Beer’s printer needs little natural binder, which makes the products endlessly recyclable. The printed objects exploit the possibilities and beauty of the technique. Tactility, bold lines and print speed result in distinctive shapes. Printed paper is surprisingly strong.

It is custom-made on a 3D-printer at home, from local plastic waste. The production is state of the art, the design old-school mechanical, its function quite symbolic: this smart adapter automatically unplugs any device after a pre-set time. With this prototype Sabine Silaraja shows that there are attractive alternatives to mass-produced, non-sustainable electronic devices from across the globe. Why not take a look at what you can create and fix yourself, right in your own home? ‘Unplug!’ brings back the cool of mechanical design: it does not use any electricity at all. Its spring-loaded timer can be set to save more electricity and shut off the intrusive bright displays in your home when the machines are done. It can be disassembled, repaired and recycled.

A collection of three rain ponchos, made for a millennial lifestyle. Each one is recyclable without disassembly due to its mono-material design from a zero-waste pattern. Sabine Silaraja set out to redesign one of the most-used items in her travelling friend’s backpack into a circular product. While the COMMUTER empowers the urban cyclist to embrace the weather, the NOMAD poncho with its tailored hood, packable size and functional versatility fits the backpacker. The ESCAPIST poncho offers comfort during a day trip or festival, with a longer back panel to sit on and a safe pocket for valuables. When designing for circularity, convenience cannot be overlooked.

An installation that explores the relationship with our forgotten urban co-inhabitants – the animals that we share our cities with. Amid our man-made cityscapes, we have become removed from nature. We rarely look beyond our own species in our daily lives, let alone in design or urban planning. With ‘Strangers in Paradise’ Lydia Halders invites us to widen our gaze to include all of the beings around us. Inspired by fellow Eindhoven dwellers such as peppered moths, foxes, pigeons, rats and bees, Lydia developed a series of concepts that embrace the full diversity of city life, both animal and human. She explores these in illustrated animations and 3D props. I want to show that the city is also a natural environment.

A floor that adds more space to small living quarters. Looking for more efficient ways to use your limited living space? ‘MoreFloor’ offers added storage to any room and frees up floor space because it clears away furniture that sits unused for large parts of the day. How about closing the lid on your sunk bed and wardrobe after your morning shower? Work or play on the floor during the day, and when you get tired, simply open up the floor and snuggle up. These elevated wooden floor elements hide furniture and storage beneath their lids that double as floor panels. Use and combine as many as you like to fit your space. Taking away just 30cms in height adds 6m2 of space!

Educational toys for puppies that stimulate bonding and good communication with their owners right from the start. The toys increase eye contact with a puppy, which is vital for these young animals. A short roll of fabric for example, brings owners up close for a game of tug-of-war. Through such play, the puppy learns core concepts such as picking things up, letting go and staying put. Each toy is made of recycled materials. If puppies are not trained to communicate with people, they are likely to develop behavioural problems. They can become nervous or aggressive and end up in an animal shelter. This can be avoided through proper socialisation. For puppies, nothing accelerates acceptance and mutual respect like play.

An initiative that brings together seniors from care centres and recent arrivals in the country in a ‘language café’. Elderly residents of care centres often have lots of time but little meaningful to do. ‘samsam’ offers them a chance to make a positive contribution to society by helping newcomers to learn Dutch through conversation lessons. The initiative champions equality, empowerment and inclusion. Lotte de Haan created an online platform (www.samsam.org) that explains how care centres can open a language café. She guides them through the process and gives them all the tools to start and sustain the language café. Everybody can be meaningful in the right context.

Material research exploring how to adapt linoleum so that it can be used in more ways. By changing the mix of components, Don Kwaning creates a viable, plant-based alternative for leather. Made of 100 per cent natural materials such as linseed oil, wood flour and pine resin, linoleum is such a beautiful material, it is a shame to only use it on the floor. Through extensive experimentation, Don developed a softer, more flexible material that shares the look and properties of leather. He used this to make wall tiles that add more atmosphere and texture to a room while also improving the acoustics. This is just one of many possible interior applications. This project was realised in collaboration with Forbo. This natural material brings interiors to life.

A book introducing young children to all the parts of the body, including the bits that parents tend to skip: the genitals. This fun, waterproof book for ages three to five, is designed to take into the bath or shower. By going from the head down to the toes, and everything in between, the book teaches children that the penis and vagina are ‘regular’ body parts just like knees, elbows or noses. Parents are often too embarrassed to name the ‘private parts,’ giving the impression that these do not exist, are not important, or are ‘dirty’. Yet, teaching kids the proper names early opens the door to talking about gender and sexuality later. It is important that we normalise the conversation about sexuality at a young age.

Connection points between the legs and surfaces of household furniture that demonstrate the potential of steel. Interested in material-led design, Johannes Böving experimented with one material — steel — to understand its limits, breaking points and durability. The knowledge gained then guided the shaping and functioning of the resulting objects. By exploring the technique of plastic deformation, where the material is put under enormous pressure until it buckles under the strain, Johannes managed to control how steel is shaped within an industrial compression machine. Discovering functions in unexpected ways through experimentation.

An exploration into the soft rush plant for use in a wide range of materials, from paper to textiles, foam, cardboard, rope and even furniture. The soft rush is primarily known from the woven Japanese tatami mats, wherein the whole plant is processed. But separating the inner core, or pith, from the outer stalk creates a wealth of possible new applications. The pith is a natural foam. With its lightweight, shock-resistant and insulating properties it is suitable as ecological packaging material. It can also be compressed into a foam block without the need for extra bonding additives. Compressing it further creates a lightweight sheet material strong enough to make into furniture. There are countless possibilities for further development. The pith of the soft rush is normally not used, despite its great potential.

Proposals for a broader use of date trees. Instead of just using the fruits, the wood can be used for construction and woodwork. In Israel, dates are a holy crop and also a booming industry, with the fruit exported to countries around the world. But the country imports nearly all of its wood products. While the fruit is eaten and the leaves are used for decoration, tons of leftover material remain after harvesting. Dan Porat wonders why the tree’s value doesn’t extend beyond food or the spiritual. Dan has made a video of his investigation and designed a series of objects made from the tree and bark. ‘Tamar’ intends to change perceptions and introduce a wider range of thought on the abundance that is locally available. Don’t see agriculture merely as a food source.

A bathing system for contemporary interiors, complete with natural linen textiles, for an inviting washing ritual that is less wasteful than a shower or a bath. Linen is highly absorbent, so Alice Guidi made use of this natural property and created three linen bathing textiles: a washcloth with a soft, felted edge for extra-sensitive areas, a chunkier knitted sponge for exfoliation, and a towel. The basin, spoon and stool enhance the ease and timeless appeal of the experience. In a world facing increasing water shortages, it is not sustainable to keep pouring litres and litres of this valuable resource down the drain. Even just a five-minute shower uses up 45 litres of water.

Two woven curtains: one for summer and one for winter. Each influences the light differently to suit changing seasonal needs. Curtains are so dominant in the interior, we should be able to adapt them to the time of year. In summer you want to filter the light and still look outside, and in winter it’s all about shutting out the cold darkness. The semitransparent summer curtain is woven to create a nuanced play of light, with a gradual shift from horizontal to vertical lines. The opaque winter version has a subtle golden shimmer on one side to reflect the light, while the pale, pink mohair on the other side creates a cozy, warm vibe. The different curtains change the interior ambience to suit the season.

A range of textiles, made of 100 per cent recycled fibres, for use in the home or any other interior application, such as upholstered fabrics, wall hangings and blankets. The textile industry is the second most polluting industry on the planet. Most end-of-life textiles are shredded and repurposed into materials of low value, such as carpet liners, insulation or movers’ blankets. Charlotte Cazals challenges our mindset by showing the potential of recycled fibres. Charlotte designed a range of textiles that showcase the aesthetic qualities of the fibres, highlighted in random patterns sprinkled on the surface. They are finely quilted for more durability and embroidered with colourful touches. More than half of fast fashion is dumped in less than a year. The textiles were produced with the help of ENKEV, a company that processes natural fibres.

Woven fabrics made from ostrich feathers that reveal the beauty of this natural material. Reviving the appeal of these feathers would also provide a much-needed boost to Oudsthoorn, South Africa, which is reliant on this once-thriving industry. In the 19th century, ostrich feathers were highly prized, adorning the flamboyant hats of many a Victorian lady. Since then, the feather has gone out of fashion, appearing mostly in tacky carnival costumes or feather dusters. The birds are currently farmed for their meat and are slaughtered after only one year. Keeping ostriches for their feathers would mean that they could live up to 35–40 years, providing feathers every six months. Collecting the feathers causes no pain to the bird. Ostrich feathers are soft, warm and incredibly light.

Six wooden tools to stimulate a range of active sitting postures throughout the day. Man was not made to sit. Man was made to move. Yet, contemporary office lifestyles are designed for us to spend entire days sitting passively behind computer screens. Our health is suffering; weakened muscles and sluggish blood circulation are reaching epidemic proportions. The stools train muscles that are unused in a conventional chair and facilitate physical fitness. One of them trains us to squat — which most adults find hard to do nowadays, due to a lack of practice. The set facilitates a diversity of movement and suits every type of office scenario, from meetings to conference calls, to computer work. As we merge with our machines, our movements are compromised.

A narrative-driven podcast program for voluntary carers: mobilising and empowering, enabling peer support, reflection, and connection with the wider community via local radio and online. The number of family carers is increasing in the context of ageing societies and cuts to services. This podcast gives them a voice, airs personal lived experiences and stories, celebrating and expressing complex and diverse identities. Refreshingly uplifting and entertaining, this project defies stereotypes of the carer’s role, offering instead a positive re-evaluation of family bonds. The format proved to be creative and engaging in the broadest sense and can be applied in communities around the world. In sharing their stories, carers can redefine who they are.

A set of borosilicate pots inspired by traditional cooking techniques. Borosilicate glass is a great material for cooking, storing and conserving food. It can withstand high temperatures and is flame-proof, rust-free, chemical-free, non-porous and non-reactive. It absorbs no flavours or odours. In ‘Al Pot Petit’, Inés Sistiaga Vidal- Ribas created a collection of pots that showcase the qualities of borosilicate glass. Portions of one or two servings determined the size of the pots, which respond to a range of applications, including open and closed preparation. Her collection is driven by a longing for slowness, for ritual, for detail. Good jam comes in small jars.

A system that combines 3D scan technologies with the tactile possibilities of knitting to create responsive textile patterns. In the area of knitted orthopaedic devices, we find an impoverished design scenario based on a standardised understanding of the body, even though all bodies are unique, as are their motion patterns. The body is not considered from the start of the design process. ‘Tailored Bond’ proposes a tailored-to-fit system based on software that translates data from a 3D MRI scan into a code for a knitting machine to understand. Parameters such as stiffness, compression, elasticity, texture, warmth and transpiration find material translation into a knitted customised brace. Material that collaborates with our individual bodies.

A printing process that reveals and exposes the unexpected aesthetic qualities of fatigue. Society is obsessed with productivity and effectivity. As a result, fatigue is viewed as a weakness. But Léa Mazy celebrates it as a strength. She believes that instead of fighting fatigue, we should recognise its creative potential in challenging the ideals and standards of mass production. Inspired by the fading quality of prints as ink cartridges run low, Léa explored how fatigue enriches the surface of printed tiles with a variety of nuances. Her process offers a positive understanding of fatigue: each tile is the unique recording of its production rhythm, offering an endless and versatile collection The hidden energy of fatigue. Sponsored by Florim Ceramiche

This series of bedroom products made from heather is a reflection on the impact great historical shifts have on human needs and activities, and thus the landscape. While industrialisation offered mankind new and much broader perspectives, it also changed our needs. Open spaces, where sheep used to graze the colourful heather, were turned into woods for timber, industrial sites, and related landscaped areas. Only a third of the original heather fields remained — as protected natural heritage. Salvo Caltabellotta uses heather as his main material and processes it using contemporary production techniques such as mechanical shaving and needle punching. He has dyed his felted and brushed textiles using pigments from the plant and following age-old recipes. Reinterpreting the traditional uses of the ubiquitous plant in pre-industrial Europe.

A community-based project that constructs new values by transforming a waste product from gold mining into glass objects. Lured to the Americas by tales of El Dorado, conquistadors exploited the gold mines of Colombia for centuries. Gold is still central to the identity of the community in the Marmato region. To reduce the environmental impact of mining, ‘Suelo Orfebre’ uses Jagua, a waste product currently discarded into the rivers. Together with the community, Colombian designer Simon Ballen built an oven and used Jagua to produce glass objects in moulds built from the surroundings. The results offer a catalogue of possibilities for the social and economic benefit of the local community. Making glass from the land of gold.

Office furniture for all who find themselves more productive when working away from the desk and its inbuilt pressure to perform. Inspired by working in bed and his ‘fear’ of the desk, Geoffrey Pascal created three pieces of furniture to recreate the laid-back postures adopted in bed. The variety of furniture allows you to adapt your posture to the task at hand. It also encourages more movement than simply sitting passively in the same chair all day long. Each piece is designed to be as close as possible to the ‘Neutral Body Posture’ developed by NASA as the ideal resting position. Working should be a more playful and attractive experience.

A study of characteristic building typologies, researching how architecture could reflect the mindset of modern society. Architecture can say a lot about the existential issues that mankind has been dealing with throughout history. By analysing and reimagining three conventional institutions, Zofia Nowakowska adds a new layer to their story, showing how the passing of time can be incorporated in static buildings. The sketches of a prison, hospital and columbarium explore today’s themes and timelines. A see-through skyscraper has 52 floors for 52 prisoners, who descend one level each week until their year of incarceration has passed. The hospital has 25 glass pavilions to facilitate a division between different age-groups. And the columbarium with unconventional funerary urns presents the lottery of life and death. The project is a study of society through the lens of architecture.

A material study of linoleum, raising it from the floor to showcase it as a precious and versatile material for a wide variety of applications. During her internship at Forbo, Kita Keus experimented with innovative adaptations of this natural material. She found a new use for old printing blocks that were originally used for colouring the products once dry. She now uses them to embosses the soft sheets at an earlier stage. By pressing the blocks into the ‘cookie’ — the name for the mixture of linseed oil, wood flour, limestone and resin — beautiful structures and perforated patterns are formed. Kita documented her various linoleum recipes in a ‘cook book’, showing interesting new possibilities for a traditional material. I have added light and texture to the recipe.

A walking route along Eindhoven’s industrial heritage, marked by urban installations on the exact location where the old factory chimneys used to stand. How can cities keep track of their history when buildings get replaced one after the other? Céline Lallau has created subtle reminders of what once was, turning historical spots into meeting points for locals and tourists. Céline proposes a partial reconstruction of vanished chimneys — creating their base, or part of it where new buildings have claimed the space. They serve as circular benches for a short rest. The interactive map in the middle has an augmented-reality code that shows the original chimney on your phone, reconnecting this era to the one before. Eindhoven’s industrial history has more than just Philips.

A study of the potential use of leftover pine resin, a cheap material readily available all over the world. Iiris Möller grew up close to forests in Finland and believes strongly in returning everything we take from the earth. Interested in finding new possibilities for biodegradable materials, she wondered whether she could make anything from pine resin besides varnish or glue. Iiris returned to the forest, the source of the material. Inspired by the sounds and play of light, she wanted to take pine resin back to where it came from. Her tiles mark a clearance in the forest, luring you beyond the paths among the trees. Pine resin disappears into the cycle of the forest, not leaving a trace.

A near future with no more plastic soap bottles, but only little soap machines that add a new ritual to daily life, helping to create a ‘happy earth’. When we buy an object we do not need, is it equivalent to buying happiness? What if we were to shift our ‘happiness’ from products to the process of production? Nothing is more comforting than a shower after a long day’s work. Instead of using soap with chemicals and unknown ingredients, we can use this machine to make soap according to our preferred recipe, giving us a happy body and a happy mind. Happy body, happy mind, happy earth.

A family of furniture that celebrates the invention of reinforced concrete 150 years ago, by revealing its inner beauty. Until now, steel reinforcements were hidden inside the concrete with one purpose only: to give the material strength. Willem van Hooff has turned the composite inside out and brings the metal grid to the surface, giving it a complementary aesthetic function. After extensive experimentation, he found a way to let the metal outgrow the concrete in the casting process. The result visualises the strong pact between the two. Together, the sculptural pieces form a new city landscape within our homes. By changing the proportions, new functions are revealed.

These windows change your view of the world. You might see double, get surprised by strange reflections, or an unexpected haze. Dané Vonk melted subtle patterns into glass, transforming life outside into a puzzling panorama. Inspired by the transformative quality of waterdrops, lenses or funhouse mirrors, ‘A Twisted View’ shows the beauty of distortion. A collection of samples to win over architects and interior designers. A metal grid with pins or holes underneath a glass plate creates organic and geometrical patterns at 660 to 750 degrees Celsius. The glass melts over the mould and takes on its new form. A window with a twist adds wonder to the world.

A new way of making coffee using the law of communicating vessels. Making a good cup of coffee takes time and care. To underline the importance of these, Dorus Pieke Paolo van Haeren has created a coffee maker that makes it worth the wait. Every aspect of the process is visible because the entire system is made of glass. Two glass vessels sit on top of each other, with a double-walled tube connecting one with the other. Ground coffee is placed in the top, boiling water is slowly added and when the level of the steeping brew reaches the height of an opening in the tube, the coffee drips down into the receptacle. Good coffee comes to those who wait.

A space-saving new take on a familiar household object. Student digs are often small and provide only a minimum of necessities. They are hardly the ideal place to dry laundry, and keeping them tidy is a challenge. The best place to dry laundry is high up in the room, because hot air rises, Jelle Heuver reasoned. He knew that historically, farmhouses in the Dutch province of Groningen featured a droogspin (literally: drying spider) to hoist up drying clothes. He reintroduces the idea, extending the item’s functionality: dry your washing, or lift up your things if you need the floor space. In this capacity the ‘Droogspin’ is also a valuable addition to small offices or studios. Make the best possible use of your small living or work space!

Modular furniture elements that can be arranged in a multitude of ways to respond to our ever-changing daily needs. The spaces we use are increasingly multifunctional; from our living room to the office, to shared public areas. This demands greater flexibility and a new kind of seating that can evolve throughout the day. With different sizes, characters and colours, the seven seating modules have been designed to be easily rearranged for different moments. One module, for instance, goes from a table to a backrest simply by flipping it over and slotting it in. Biodegradable granules and memory foam enable the elements to mould themselves around the body for maximum support and comfort. My designs are made to invite more interaction between people.

These tiles are designed to cover entire buildings — roofs and walls alike. Next to a visual makeover, they also offer a solution for damp walls: the curved shape allows a natural flow of air below them, and the glazed surface effectively directs the rain down. It is time for a renewal of ornamental architecture, says Freek Peters. Inspired by the Amsterdam School style, with roof tiles on the upper part of outer walls, he expands their range even further. The look may be something else, but the material and production process are age-old. The tiles are made at the Wienerberger ceramic factory in Peter’s home village of Tegelen (which happens to be Dutch for ‘to tile’). Tiles that fit your house like the feathers of a bird.

Building blocks made from unrecyclable fibres from the paper recycling industry. The blocks function as elements for assembling several pieces, such as shelves, stools and benches. Cellulose paper fibres can only be recycled five to seven times. A single recycling plant utilises up to 4000 tons of these unrecyclable fibres every year. In ‘Recycling Reject’, Tim Teven wanted to find a purpose for seemingly unrecyclable fibres generated by the paper recycling industry. By shredding and drying the leftover fibres, adding binder and pigment, and then moulding them under pressure. The resulting material is hard and strong, like stone or brick, with a smooth surface. I’m interested to see what designers and factories can do for each other.

An installation in a public space that creates a modicum of privacy while promoting a communal atmosphere, much like the situation between two neighbouring backyards separated by a fence. Independence and privatisation have limited our connections with other people, leaving us isolated. While we claim to celebrate diversity and social exchange, we erect walls that make us indifferent and avoid unwanted communication. While walls definitively separate, fences define territory yet are porous and allow for interaction. With her ‘Bonding Boundary’, Julia Owczarczak arranged fixed and mobile elements that create constantly changing and gentle divisions into zones, enabling people to reconsider their relations with one another in space. The culture of fences is the culture of dialogue.

An installation space where visitors can experience technology in a personal and interactive way, allowing for more emotional involvement. Animate curtains, each with its own characteristics respond to your presence. One whizzes past upon entrance, showing the way forward, another envelopes you as you sit on a chair, inviting a moment of privacy. Set in the interior, the objects explore how to communicate with those using the space and care for them in a sensually perceptible way. The project opposes the common vision of a ‘smart home’ where a large number of invisible and unnoticeable services are blended into the background — impalpable and distant. How close do we feel to the digital tools that surround us?

An open catalogue that displays an alternative reading of ordinary objects to emphasise the importance of freedom of expression. From Molotov cocktails made out of preserved pickles during the Hungarian Uprising to the pots and pans used to express dissent during the Pinochet dictatorship in Chile, people often adapt and reinterpret mundane things to challenge authority. ‘Everyday Exception’ shows how we all design without being ‘formal’ designers. Mariangela Beccoi compiled an open catalogue of objects that we can deploy in an unusual context, enabling everybody to become an ‘everyday designer’. Different objects convey different notions, such as confrontation (four slippers), asymmetry (bar of soap and 150 nails), dialogue (funnels and tube) and hierarchy (broomstick with two brush heads). Domestic space becomes a space for political expression.

Reflecting on the powers that dictate our health routines in the context of increasingly digitised and efficient workspaces. How much does an environment affect the physique of a worker? How far is the millennial willing to go to achieve physical ‘perfection’ within their working routine? Of-Labour Systems’ is Rob Johnson’s fictional narrative that fuses the cultures of work and fitness, valuing our voluntary exhaustion as a precious commodity. The solo work station is designed around small gestures at the desk — balance seating, lighting manipulated by the heart rate, and full body choreography to ‘activate’ the desk and chair. The seating area includes a running machine for fitness fanatics. How far is too far in a fitness- obsessed world?

Architectural archetypes, such as a threshold, window and wall, that reflect our modern experience of home as a hybrid of multiple geographic contexts. Increasing migration is provoking a shift in our concepts of home and belonging, especially in relation to the temporary spaces we inhabit. Today, home as a utopia is unattainable for most. Yet, it is also suggested everywhere through the commodification of the feeling of home. And so it is time to redraw the archetypes that we have in our minds. By merging standard Polish and Dutch housing elements, Karolina Michalik explores ‘familiar’ and ‘foreign’ ideas of what the notion of home entails. Her hybrids offer a means to step away from set concepts and engage with alternatives. Exploring the fluid boundary between the 'Heimlich' and 'Unheimlich' of the modern home.

The discovery of black salsify (schorseneren) and dandelions as a viable source of bioplastic as well as of food, for people and livestock. Latex is a natural polymer produced by over 12,500 plant species. Marco Cagnoni narrowed this group down to two species that are ideal for making bioplastic. Flexible and long-lasting, this material can replace most synthetic polymers. The plants are also highly nutritious, so you can make plastic and produce food, instead of using valuable staple foods to make plastic. Rice, potatoes, corn, cassava and sugarcane are the most common sources for current bioplastics. But, with a rapidly expanding global population, turning carbohydrates into plastic is not logical or ethical. Why waste food on bioplastic when you can make bioplastic and food from one plant?

An artificial intelligence platform that will guide you on a journey of self-discovery. The saturation of daily life with digital technology has changed the way we see ourselves, generating existential crises, anxiety and disconnection. In an era of excess information, we need a way to reflect on our own thoughts. Say hello to ‘An I’, a device that allows you to have conversations that you wouldn’t like to have with anyone else but yourself. This digital version of you talks to you, knows you, understands you and learns from you. Taking care of yourself constitutes not only a principle but a constant practice.

A mobile public toilet for women that addresses the gender inequality and discrimination inherent in the current lack of such facilities for women. There are plenty of urinals for men scattered around the city. So why is there nothing for women? For Elisa Otañez, this is an example of the persistent sexism built into daily existence. The arresting yellow colour of the cubicle and the bold typeface emblazoned across the sides uses the visual language of activism to highlight the need for change. The temporary nature of the cubicle is a critique of the fact that there is nothing permanent yet in place. Why are toilets a public good accessible almost exclusively to men?

A reinterpretation of autonomy applied to city life. Society relies so heavily on interconnections that a more autonomous existence is unattainable. Or is it? If we think of autonomy as an attitude of wonder and investigation, not as an end, we can engage with our surroundings again. In ‘A Matter of Autonomy’, Julia Laporte explores how we can develop an investigative attitude towards cities. Her machine — a combination of vacuum cleaner, sausage extruder and hotspot — collects freely available and undervalued material such as water, dust and potatoes and turns them into temporary objects. The freedom of intervention offers a vivid approach to the city. My dream journey invites people to rethink their surroundings.

A game that draws on the vocabulary of sport to design bodily experiences in which social norms are performed and deconstructed. Sport is more than physical activity. It is also a power structure that reinforces normative logic and positions identities in a disciplined framework. In ‘Multiform’, Gabriel Fontana took the sports field as a micro- environment where he could find out how patterns of behaviour reflect their wider social context. Gabriel developed a game in which sport becomes a metaphor for exploring how people interact in daily life, from the uniforms we identify with to the specific roles accorded to us in a group. Sport is the perfect tool for changing the rules of a wider social game.

A travelling archive and workshop visualising a range of textiles coloured with urine. The aim is to create a closer relationship between our daily behaviour, our bodies and the environment. Urine has long been used as a natural fixative to dye textiles because of its ammonia content. Now Louise Permiin uses urine-based textile dyes to reveal societal information. The colour of our urine is a daily record of the food, medicines and chemicals we consume. Some effects are plainly visible. Others, like Bisphenol A — a substance in plastics, cans and receipts — only appear after chemical tests. Louise indicates its presence with a blue square on the fabric. Different colours could be used to signify other chemicals. This private biomaterial is an informative, poetic and rich resource.

Exploring parallels between the basketry technique of coiling and 3D printing. The result is an archive of diverse artefacts ranging from samples and experiments to functional objects — a testimony to the value of design as a collaborative process. Usually designers only seek craft knowledge in the production phase, and not during the research beforehand. With ‘Crossing parallels’, Amandine David involved craft masters right from the start to discover extra creative opportunities. By working together with master basket weaver Esmé Hofman and 3D-printing artisan Joris van Tubergen, the value of the work goes beyond a final object, sharing the failures and innovations happening at every stage of the process. I want to explore learning as a design approach.

Ways to rebuild the endangered ecosystem of local manufacturing. Globalisation has spelt the end of many small-scale industries. In ‘Building the Local’, Ellie Birkhead reacts to this issue in the context of the Chiltern Hills in south-east England. Her project considers local crafts as an essential aspect of cultural identity and a sense of place. Ellie introduced waste products — spent grain from breweries, recycled glass from pubs, waste from farms — from neighbouring industries into the brickmaking process. ‘Building the Local’ enhances the traditional brick with new connections, thereby rebuilding the endangered ecosystem of local manufacturing. Can the unassuming brick become the icon for the future of craft and industry?

An installation to consider the importance given to beauty, inspired by the historical boudoir as a space charged with sexuality and female empowerment. Beauty has largely been commodified and attention paid to this aspect of self-care is often criticised as superficial, only going skindeep. And yet, we remain preoccupied with it as a representation of the self. So why not give ourselves room to acknowledge the aesthetics that shape us? Marine uses skin to symbolise the relationship between our inner and outer self. Using her own skin tones, she furnishes her boudoir with the flat silhouettes of the furniture traditionally found there, as if each piece has shed off its own image. Finally, an intimate space to reconcile our inner and outer self.

A set of garden furniture, made from manually split wood, which was designed in collaboration with a locally sourced 60-year-old Robinia tree trunk. The industrial processing of wood leaves it vulnerable to decay and accounts for the necessity of toxic preservatives. Split wood is naturally better able to resist weather damage and makes the most of the valuable qualities inherent in the material. Storing the objects in an angled position allows water to run off quickly. Surfaces that are in contact with the soil are scorched to give extra protection. Instead of permanently appropriating the wood, I only borrow it.

The necessity of educating our bodies through choreographed storylines that provoke behavioural change. With the rise of xenophobia and polarisation, subtle sense-oriented interventions can be a powerful tool for challenging our preconceptions about others. In the educational programme of the ‘United Negotiation of Otherness’, Vivien Tauchmann emphasises the importance of body language, gestures and movement in turning away from visually learned stereotypes and focusing on embodied experiences rather than on media imagery. She turns the designer and participants into both material and research tool, helping us understand how we feel about other people and what their experiences may be. Empathy is an active state of mind through which we can connect with others.

Three toys — a ball, a rope and a hoop — fitted with sensors that activate a digital interface. The toys have all the traditional benefits in terms of physical exertion and social interaction. But the addition of a digital layer expands the experience of play, thereby motivating and stimulating children. These responsible objects for future generations counter the negative effects of digitally immersive activities. The digital layer makes traditional toys contemporary by incorporating elements familiar from video games and social media. These make them interesting for children who increasingly engage with the world through smartphones and tables.

Exploring the potential of emerging biotechnology to create artificial animal parts for use in traditional Chinese medicine. This would avoid putting more wild animals in danger. There is a huge demand for wild animal parts in traditional Chinese medicine, which forms a real threat to conservation. Yet, it is a shame to write off thousands of years of medical practice, believes Kuang- Yi Ku. Instead of killing wild animals, why not grow the part required in a lab? Or perhaps consider merging elements from Asian and Western traditions together, such as a tiger penis and an oyster — both believed to increase libido. In this way, Kuang-Yi proposes to bridge the conflict between cultural heritage and the environment. Traditional Chinese medicine can still be valuable.

Drop your old smartphone inside and this machine grinds it to bits, destroying any residual personal data. It is also the first step in the recycling process. A photo of the crushed pieces pops out afterwards as proof of a job well done. What to do with our outdated phones? There is no clear next step. Donating them often does more harm than good; after just a few years of use they end up as toxic garbage in faraway countries. Every phone contains some 42 precious materials. These can best be recycled safely and locally. Like an old-fashioned photo booth, the machine could become a standard public fixture. It is extra noisy to make its presence known. Crushing your old smartphone is an opportunity to redefine its value.
Lucy is a sweet little thing, but, Ew! what ís all that stuff growing there on her body?  Let’s get it away, get your razor and, quick, let nobody see,  the long black hairs that grow effortlessly.

Cultural misappropriation distinguishes itself from cultural exchange, appreciation and appropriation due to the adoption of elements of a minority culture by members of a dominant culture. Employing the 2019 Spring/Summer fashion collection as a case study, Bohwa Jang studies the misappropriation of ornaments and patterns in Western fashion today. With Patterns in Circulation she develops a clothing collection for today’s European political elite.

titel: Today I Am Not Going to Save the World
inhoud: A question that we inevitably pose to ourselves is how can we deal with stress and the boredom of everyday life. Together with Herbo, the spirit animal and star of the show, Cato Stigter developed five ways of finding ourselves and bringing our inner tranquillity back. Today I Am Not Going to Save the World shows you how you can free your mind from stress, and expand your consciousness, how you can share your grooviness and make spiritual connections, and how you can focus more on life and find your inner Original Gangster spirit.

If I remember well, this project started because you realised that working on prestigious cultural assignments lowers your chance of achieving the bourgeois well-off existence, which according to Western conventions comprises a house, backyard and a 65-zoll 4K TV. The contradiction is that you never wanted this house; as a child you drew this house sloppily probably on purpose.

The Sámi people have been residing in the northernmost part of Europe for more than 10.000 years. But nowadays the newly established Nordic nation states claim their land. However even now independent Saamiland is alive in the minds of its people. Typography and language are integral tools in creating nation states. The same tools were used to oppress the Sámi. Working together with Sámi language typographers, linguists and the Sámi parliament, Risto Kujanpää designed a typeface that aims to include, rather than oppress. 2019 is the International Year of Indigenous Languages. According to the initiators Unesco and UN, “most indigenous languages are in danger, even though they are the main conveyors of knowledge that provide original solutions to contemporary challenges.”

titel: The Small Space of a Pause
inhoud: Space is a container of past and future, memory and imagination, limitations and potential. Fluidity is the ability to sense the rhythm, in order to move within space. It’s the ability to (un)learn. It’s the awareness of a universal open space, instead of a space divided by perceived walls. It’s the awareness of self in context of, and the awareness of self in any context. In her project, Kerrin Go attempts to place visitors in the present time and space. She uses the academy and its renovation to make them part of her installation and asks them to look beyond it. In the small space of a pause, there’s infinity.

titel: the future is tentacular: making kin and other gestures
inhoud: This project begins with introducing tentacular thinking and making kin as feminist alternative practices to individualist, corporate feminism. These terms offer possibilities to think institutions and relations outside of their normative and patriarchal formations. But what exactly is tentacular thinking? The journey to uncover this term is what this project is about. By setting up experiments, actions, and gestures, Carolina Valente Pinto is growing tentacles in a project space made of a web of collective knowledges–and making kin in between everyone in the process. Tentacular thinking shows how decentralising, expanding, unmaking and tying knots builds generative and generous worlds towards the future.

A balcony, unlike a terrace or loggia, is cellular and isolated. Standing on a balcony, one has the privilege of greater privacy, elevation, and breadth of view. Continuum Elevation explores power relations inherent to verticality – the shift in perspective that divides the ones above from the ones below. The video installation traces the notion of verticality in today’s world – a time characterised by “seeing all”, with scant knowledge and interest in those on the ground.

Given the speed and ease of digital communication, we are presented merely with a facade. Not only does the facade hide a mountain of mediation, it makes communication seem simple and frictionless. We are surrounded by a network that none of us notice but all of us use. Wietske Nutma traces the route of a single text message between sender and receiver. She gives an account of its intimacy, the time and distance of its travel, narrating us through the rules and infrastructures that govern our means of communication.

ssssssssssshhhhhhhh… tap tap tap… pat… *sniffle*…*silence* …patter patter patter. You listen carefully, as a hand gently interacts with a freshly unboxed MacBook Pro with a Touch Bar and Touch ID with 2.4GHz Quad-Core Processor and Turbo Boost up to 4.1GHz 256GB Storage. Through a series of rendered ASMR videos, Samuel Rynearson brings together contemporary and ancient tools as subjects of fascination. Autonomous sensory meridian response (ASMR) is a calming, pleasurable feeling often accompanied by a tingling sensation.

Why do we still use and reproduce a typeface that originated 500 years ago while our living conditions have drastically changed? Type can serve as an archaeological object that tells us as much about its own past as about how we view history more broadly: design, usage, technological developments, commercial market goals and socio-political circumstances are all reflected. 500 Versions of Garamond is an interactive installation that takes Garamond as a case study to reveal the factors that make a typeface survive.

We exist in a reality where developers define the human condition and train computational systems to understand and describe our personal experiences in abstract languages, with the intention of recognizing anomalous events and deviant behaviour. In this project, Roslana Yotova explores alternative modes of social presence and interactions, meant as performative tools for masking visibility in order to confront such predictive technologies. Rolling your body in a circular shape and performing rotational movements while supporting yourself with your hands, or forming joint compositions with partners are some of the methods she employs.

We are walking through the basement–where information is altered as documents transfer from material to immaterial carriers.
